The school is for pupils aged 5-16 years old and was designed to include practical spaces such as Art, Food Technology and Science. epe_description_2: I worked within the multi-disciplinary design team, alongside the client team and the Academy Trust to develop the FFE designs for the specialist teaching areas, sensory rooms. epe_description_3: With no cohort or academy trust identified in the early stages of the design, we relied on our experience and knowledge gained from designing specialist schools in the past to develop the building design and layout that would be flexible and adaptable enough to suit the yet unknown cohort. epe_description_2: I was responsible for the interior design and specifications which were carefully designed to support the nature of the cohort with considered use colour, flexible furniture and comforting break out spaces that can adapt to suit the special needs of the pupils.
epe_description_3: The specification was developed closely with the client and Academy to ensure additional robustness and safety aspects to suit the needs of the pupils attending, balanced to ensure a home from home environment was provided for the residential units.

epe_description_1: The project is a major refurbishment and adaptation to parts of a Town Hall to improve the visitor experience, diversify/maximise opportunities for revenue generation, improve accessibility and sensitively restore key heritage areas in scope. The project is funded by a Town fund, as part of the Levelling Up initiative. The scope of works includes restoration of a Hall, including compliant fire strategy for increased occupancy, restored seating and new staging/AV system. There is also to be a new café and ancillary areas on the lower ground floor, along with a new accessible entrance to reinstate the historic frontage.
epe_description_2: My role to date has been primarily an overseeing project management function and CDM-PD from RIBA Stages 2-4. We’ve worked closely with the conservation officer in striving to meet compliance aspects such as ventilation and accessibility without detracting from the heritage setting.
epe_description_3: The primary challenges have been in managing the limited funding budget set against competing agendas (quality of theatre experience, quality of finish, accessibility etc) and a myriad of condition issues (fabric, M&E etc). The unknown building infrastructure (e.g. the Hall ventilation system) has necessitated camera and smoke surveys alongside extensive opening up to establish potential design solutions.

epe_description_1: The project involved the replacement of a condemned modular building with external works to house the school-run two-year-olds provision. Provided supervision to the project architect at feasibility stage to establish the scope of works and brief requirements. epe_description_2: I was responsible for facilitating discussions between the client, school and modular contractor to agree choices on finishes, reviewed the contractor’s proposals for practicality and technical compliance, and acted as contract administrator during the construction phase including arranging and minuting site progress meetings.
epe_description_3: Whilst this was a relatively straightforward project, the key challenges were in procurement of the modular contractor via a framework that had expired, and construction logistics on a tight road network and live school site. epe_description_1: The client’s brief was for a 30 place Specially Resourced Provision (SRP) for Autism at a Secondary Academy in the area. The school had identified two underused spaces in the existing first floor LRC and ground floor former 6th Form Base that could be remodelled for this purpose. To exploit opportunities for shared resources, the SRP was proposed to sit directly adjacent their established SEN base and maximise benefit of the existing separate entrance. The LRC would then be relocated downstairs to the former 6th Form Base to form a contemporary, central and accessible whole-school facility. Pupils also have access to their own external play space, which extends the curriculum to the outside. This includes a vegetable garden, quiet shaded seating areas and sensory play.

epe_description_2: From RIBA Stages 1-3 I was the lead architect and lead consultant overseeing a multi-disciplinary team which included a fire engineer, building services engineers, a structural engineer and a building surveyor helping to ensure co-ordination of design. epe_description_1: This is a large special educational needs (SEN) school in the county, with three-storey, two-storey and single-storey areas, with a mixture of pitched and flat roofs. The building includes an attached dining hall and sports hall. The superstructure is a steel frame with precast concrete planks, designed and detailed in accordance with disproportionate collapse requirements set out in Building Regulations Part A3 for a Category 2b building. Due to the length of the building a structural movement joint was included where the building changes angle on plan. The substructure is a CFA (Continuous Flight Auger) pile and reinforced concrete ground beam foundation solution under the three-storey area and traditional strip and pad foundations elsewhere, with suspended precast concrete beam and block ground floor throughout.
epe_description_2: I was the Lead Structural Engineer from Concept through Detailed Design and Construction, carrying out design calculations and drawings for the project as well as liaising with the Contractor during construction.
epe_description_3: Due to the length and angle change of the building a movement joint was required through the primary structure. Complex structural detailing was carried out with coordination from other disciplines to enable construction and allow both sides of the building to expand and contract without a build-up of stresses. To save on costs and minimise embodied carbon, the foundation solution also varied across the building, using the movement joint as a natural division. The three-storey area was piled, with reinforced ground beams, and the remaining areas constructed on traditional pad and strip footings. At the interface, dowelled joints have been used to minimise differential settlement.

epe_description_1: This project is a three-storey standalone teaching block with attached dining hall and kitchen. The teaching block contains general and IT classrooms as well as design and technology workshops. The superstructure is a steel frame with precast concrete planks, designed and detailed in accordance with disproportionate collapse requirements set out in Building Regulations Part A3 for a Category 2b building. The substructure is a CFA (Continuous Flight Auger) pile and reinforced concrete ground beam foundation solution, with suspended precast concrete beam and block ground floor.
epe_description_2: I was the Lead Structural Engineer from Concept through Detailed Design and Construction, carrying out design calculations and drawings for the project as well as liaising with the Contractor during construction.
epe_description_3: Foundation construction during extremely wet weather required working closely with the Contractor to coordinate day joint positions with complex reinforcement arrangements. This enabled safer and timely construction despite the weather and was combined with utilising Hy-Rib formwork to reduce operator risk. The steel superstructure was carefully coordinated with complex mechanical ventilation routes during design stages through the use of 3D BIM, incorporating secondary steel trimmers and letter box openings through primary beams. This had the benefit of reducing cost through shallower build-ups and minimising the risk of on-site delays.

epe_description_1: This is a specialist school created by the merger of two Schools, which occupied two adjacent sites. The school provides care and education for students aged 3 to 19. Following the merger, a range of separate works across the school were identified as necessary to consolidate the sites and to accommodate an increase in capacity from 165 to 210 pupil places. Multiple deficiencies had been identified through a previous SEN report prepared by SWN for the County Council. These included insufficient DT/workshop space, inadequate internal sports accommodation, the absence of a roadway connecting the two main school sites, and the need for a safe and secure pickup/drop-off area. One phase of work involved the construction of a new multi-use hall, parking area, and pickup road system, providing a central landmark building that physically connected the two existing sites. A second phase involved the construction of a new vocational workshop with a secure, covered external paved area, allowing it to function as an outdoor classroom.
epe_description_2: My initial responsibilities involved assisting and supporting with the Stage 03 design. At Stage 04, I became lead designer for the technical design of the workshop, coordinating works between all consultants. I also provided technical support to the lead architect for the sports hall portion of the project.
epe_description_3: During Stage 05, the lead architect retired, and I assumed full design responsibility for the entire project, working closely with the contractor to deliver a high-quality outcome. A particular challenge arose due to the absence of the original lead architect during Stage 05, as progressive design decisions and remained only in his knowledge, and given the complexity of the site there had been lots of iterative design. We successfully navigated this by relying on the strength of the construction package and maintaining clear communication and coordination between SWN and the contractor. We also were able to consult previous email chains, and stored files to validate information. Another complication involved a change in use for the workshop. Initially designed as a vehicular and plumbing workshop, the school’s new management revised its requirements during construction. Nordwick worked collaboratively with the school and contractor to rapidly revise and agree on a design that accommodated the new requirements at the start of Stage 05.

epe_description_1:
This high profile project involved the re-ordering of the pedestrian circulation for a large 1968 development of deck access flats. This involved the demolition of various walkways, bridges and stairs and their replacement by new controlled access points. This re-design also demanded a full landscaping and external works package including vehicular access, parking and block assigned defensible spaces for tenants.
The buildings themselves were over-clad, re-roofed and insulated.
epe_description_2:
I formulated the design language for the scheme, conceptualised the external environment and managed a team producing the working drawings package
Any specific
epe_description_3:
All dwellings were occupied during the works. Rainwater drainage presented a challenge and necessitated a complete re-routing above ground and incorporation of this with the new design ethos. New external areas also required a major attenuation strategy to be implemented.
Some of the existing buildings were of cantilevered reinforced concrete which had been originally designed to the absolute minimum structural requirement meaning that no additional loads could be applied. A bespoke over cladding system had therefore to be developed working as an integrated design team. A further difficulty presented itself when a number of structural concrete cross walls (up to 6 storeys high) were found to contain no reinforcement.
The works themselves had to be coordinated with the renewal of a district heating system taking place concurrently. The scale of the works were reflected by the fact that the largest mobile crane in Europe was employed during construction as well as a majority of the scaffolding available in the area. This latter factor governed and limited the overall programme.
Finally, the site itself was in an area of high social risk requiring guidance and safeguarding for site operatives/ Gang activity, serious assault and even murders within the site boundaries were not unknown.

epe_description_1: The new three-storey teaching block at the Academy was designed to support the school’s growing student population and curriculum needs. The electrical services work included significant infrastructure upgrades aligned with modern educational standards, site supervision and handover procedures.
epe_description_2: In my role as an Electrical Engineer, I was responsible for overseeing the delivery of electrical systems during the construction and completion phases of the new teaching block. I worked closely with the contractors to ensure that the electrical installations met the project specifications, statutory requirements, and the client’s operational needs. My involvement included reviewing technical submittals, attending site progress meetings, inspecting works for quality and compliance, and supporting the commissioning and handover process.
epe_description_3: The electrical systems required close coordination with architectural, HVAC, and ICT designs to prevent clashes and support efficient installation. Additionally, a large solar photovoltaic (PV) system was integrated to help lower energy costs and reduce the school's carbon footprint and help achieve an ‘A+’ rated EPC.

epe_description_1: The project forms a major part of a wider housing growth programme for local Council. It aims to promote sustainable and economic growth by providing housing as the city grows. It supports the objective of Sustainable and Inclusive Growth by increasing quality housing options and spans 2nr local sites, providing 55nr housing units of various internal configurations and a further 8nr dwellings in Seacroft with an independent apartment block of 25nr lettable units.
epe_description_2: Working in the capacity of Project Quantity Surveyor from RIBA 5.
epe_description_3: The development of these two sites has been very rewarding to see coming into fruition. Dealing with a competent Tier 1 contractor has been challenging at times. However, with constant scrutiny and due diligence in valuations and cost reporting it has meant the Client has been regularly updated in any commercial abnormalities.

epe_description_1: The project involves the heritage refurbishment of a victorian Market building. The proposed works include internal structural, architectural, mechanical and electrical alteration works to the building and market roof ahead of the fit out of the building spaces.
epe_description_2: Working in the capacity of Project Quantity Surveyor from RIBA 5.
epe_description_3: Working on a Heritage site has resulted in many unknowns being presented. Through surveys undertaken before commencement of works we have been able to identify possible challenges and plan for impacts and taken steps to mitigate where possible. Additional challenges include the coordination of various subconsultants and their subsequent impact on programme delays. There have been a few L&E and EoTs granted due to unforeseen additional works which have challenged the Client’s project budget. As the QS on the project, I work closely with the Client to enable steps to be taken to minimise the commercial impact of these additional works and continue to bring the project forward.

epe_description_1: Project for the refurbishment and new-build extension of school facilities covering 5-19 year and to provide one of the UK’s first Studio schools.
epe_description_2: Team lead. Designer.
epe_description_3: The building was designed in accordance with sustainable principles and was constructed largely from innovative recycled materials. The school is naturally ventilated and cooled in addition to being equipped with a low energy heating system. The project arose from a feasibility study for the campus on an alternative proposal but which led to us understanding their requirements in depth and suggesting a different approach.

epe_description_1: I  was engaged as a framework designer for a private firm on various refurbishment and new build projects on MoD bases across the South East of England.
epe_description_2: As Operations Manager, I had to ensure fully compliant design solutions within strict security and operating limits within the air bases.
epe_description_3: The strict security and design requirements of the MoD Base Design Standards required careful scrutiny of design solutions in terms of quality, safety and deliverability.

epe_description_1: New build 2 storey primary school on greenfield site.
epe_description_2: CDM and BSAct Advisor.
epe_description_3: Fire doorsets as supplied were not in accordance with the requirements of the FOA criteria. Additional hinges retrospectively fitted to ensure certified integrity

epe_description_1: New build sheltered housing scheme. Your
epe_description_2: Client CDM Advisor.
epe_description_3: Coordinating site facilities to maintain fire service access to adjacent occupied residential properties throughout the works.

epe_description_1: Removal of AIB from common service riser & reinstatement to maintain fire integrity.
epe_description_2: Risk & Compliance Surveyor
epe_description_3: The common ventilation duct constructed of aluminium and therefore reinstatement designed and constructed as vertical fire protected riser with AT grilles as required.

epe_description_1: New Build Crematorium Design in an existing cemetery. Facilities include main entrance & porte cochere, non-denominational ceremonial space, crematorium plant area for two electric cremators and staff & admin area. The external area includes a large porte cochere and hearse approach and extensive landscaping including a memorial garden.
epe_description_2: Lead Designer from RIBA Stage 1-RIBA Stage 3; TA role from Stage 4 onwards
epe_description_3: Challenging public engagement meetings with angry local residents. We asked specialist crematoria consultants and local ward councillors to attend which helped address some of the issues that residents had.

epe_description_1: New build dual purpose building, including a school for pupils age 11-16 with behavioural and emotional needs that have been excluded from main stream education and Family Resistance Centre, a facility to provide help and support with trauma and to provide educational skills for young people.
epe_description_2: Lead Designer from RIBA Stage 1-RIBA Stage 3; TA role from Stage 4 onwards
epe_description_3: Design of dual-purpose building that includes shared spaces for staff interaction; A number of different stakeholders, including the school, FRC staff & met police had to be consulted on a regular basis during the design process.

epe_description_1: This project encompassed three phases for a 2FE Expansion of the existing 6FE secondary school. This phase included a new 2 storey building to accommodate 8 classrooms, group rooms, staff accommodation and ancillary spaces.
epe_description_2: Lead Designer from RIBA Stage 2; Designer from Stage 0-2; TA role from Stage 4 onwards
epe_description_3: Post planning changing to convert part of the building into an ASD unit and re-apply for planning permission.

epe_contract_type: JCT Standard Building Contract with Quantities 2016
epe_description_1: A demanding project consisting of a Dining hall extension, new library, and internal refurbishments, which as located within the heart of the school which remained fully operational throughout construction.
epe_description_2: The Feasibility Study for this project was written by a colleague from who I took over as Lead Designer and Contract Administrator through the RIBA Stages from 2 to 6.
epe_description_3: The project was particularly challenging as it affected some of the main elements of the existing school, namely the reception office and dining hall extension to the front of the school to form a dining hall, and the courtyard infill to form a library, which involved working in the centre of a live school environment. These challenges were met through careful programming and coordination with the main contractor, resulting in an excellent addition to the school

epe_description_1: Nestled between the historic towns of REMOVED-NAME and REMOVED-NAME, this scheme at REMOVED-NAME comprised of the development of 162 new houses and apartments which catered to a broad market, improving sales potential. Developed over 5 phases, this project revitalised a previously underused area, enhancing the developer’s portfolio and reputation.
epe_description_2: My role was to provide employer’s agent and quantity surveying services.
epe_description_3: The original developer went into administration. We were asked to procure a new contractor to complete the project. Challenges included securing warranties for partly constructed structures. The NHBC were bought in to check the structures prior to the new Contractor being appointed. A Clerk of Works was also brought in to the team to review the work undertaken to date.

epe_description_1: This High School, located in in the area, is a mixed academy for students aged 11 to 16. This project saw the design and construction of a new stand-alone specialist resource base (SRB). It was designed to support up to 25 students with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) with a tailored and enabling environment that helps students overcome learning barriers and integrate into mainstream education where possible.
epe_description_2: My role was to undertake quantity surveying services
epe_description_3: The project is currently at Stage 3 with the Contractor currently working under a Letter of Intent to prepare the planning submission. The planning process has been lengthy due to BNG requirements. This project was tendered on a design and build procurement route. With hindsight it may have been more beneficial to undertake a traditional procurement option so that all design and planning issues are resolved prior to the Contractor being appointed.

epe_description_1: This project is a residential development which includes a mix of private sale, shared ownership and affordable rent homes. The development provided much-needed affordable and market housing in a growing area, contributing to local housing supply.
epe_description_2: My role was EA/QS for Housing Association 2.
epe_description_3: The scheme was delayed due to Covid and problems with s278 approvals. There were significant design changes which resulted in a large amount of variations and additional cost. It was my responsibility to manage and advise the client on.

epe_description_1: This project involved the refurbishment of areas within the existing Academy School to provide new science laboratories, library area, music rooms, and an inclusion suite. The electrical services work included the initial feasibility survey, full design and preparation of specifications and drawings, tender assessment and site supervision.
epe_description_2: I was responsible for the complete design and delivery of electrical services across all RIBA stages, from initial feasibility assessments through to detailed design, tender evaluation, and on-site supervision. My role included producing technical drawings and specifications, reviewing contractor designs, and supporting project delivery throughout construction. The design included all key systems: power distribution, small power, energy efficient lighting with adjustable controls, emergency lighting, fire alarms, data and communication networks, and security systems such as access control and CCTV.
epe_description_3: The electrical design process required close and continuous coordination with architectural layouts, HVAC systems, and ICT infrastructure to prevent spatial conflicts and support efficient installation. Working within live school environments added complexity, necessitating careful planning to minimise disruption to teaching. This was achieved through proactive engagement with school staff, strategic scheduling of out-of-hours inspections, and clear, consistent communication throughout the project.

epe_description_1: This school is a small, community-focused school serving children aged 4–11. In 2022, the school underwent essential electrical upgrade works to improve safety and efficiency, supporting its ongoing development. The school is a fully electric Net Zero in operation school with a design focused on sustainability, safety, and functionality.
epe_description_2: Electrical Services carried out (RIBA Stages 1–6) covered the full design and delivery process, including early feasibility surveys, detailed design, drawings and specifications, contractor design review, tender evaluation, and on-site supervision. The design included all key systems: power distribution, small power, solar PV, energy-efficient lighting with adjustable controls, emergency lighting, fire alarms, data and communication networks, and security systems such as access control and CCTV.
epe_description_3: To meet the project's Net Zero requirements, a large-scale solar PV system had to be integrated into the site. This required significant modifications to the building’s fabric and included the installation of a solar canopy over the external dining and classroom areas, to support the panels and deliver long-term reductions in operational costs.

epe_description_1: This SEN School is a new SEN school set in five acres of space in the area. It's a special school for students aged 5-16 with communication and interaction difficulties.
epe_description_2: Electrical services work covered everything from an initial feasibility survey to full design, preparation of specifications and drawings, tender assessment, and site supervision. The SEN school’s electrical systems were carefully designed with safety, accessibility, and functionality in mind. These included power distribution, small power installation, energy-efficient lighting with adjustable controls, emergency lighting, fire alarms (including suppression systems), data and communication networks, and security features like access control and CCTV.
epe_description_3: To promote sustainability, Solar PV was incorporated, helping reduce energy costs and carbon footprint while offering an educational opportunity for students to learn about renewable energy. Sensory-friendly lighting and sound systems were incorporated throughout the project to create a comfortable and non-disruptive environment for students with diverse needs. Specialist lighting controls were included to enhance user flexibility and energy savings.

epe_description_1: This is a community primary school located in the area. It serves children aged 4 to 11. This project was tasked to complete a new 2 storey 2 FE primary school to replace an old Victorian school to offer modern facilities while maintaining its strong values of kindness, resilience, and aspiration.
epe_description_2: Electrical Services (RIBA Stages 1–6) covered the full design and delivery process, including early feasibility surveys, detailed design, drawings and specifications, contractor design review, tender evaluation, and on-site supervision. The design included all key systems: power distribution, small power, solar PV, energy-efficient lighting with adjustable controls, emergency lighting, fire alarms, data and communication networks, and security systems such as access control and CCTV.
epe_description_3: The electrical systems required close coordination with architectural, HVAC, and ICT designs to prevent clashes and support efficient installation. Additionally, a large solar photovoltaic (PV) system was integrated to help lower energy costs and reduce the school's carbon footprint and help achieve an ‘A’ rated EPC.

epe_description_1: Electrical services surveys were conducted to evaluate the condition, functionality, and compliance of systems across several schools in the city.
epe_description_2: The assessments covered power distribution, lighting, emergency systems, fire alarms, data and communication networks, and security infrastructure. Any defects, inefficiencies, or necessary upgrades were identified to ensure safety, reliability, and adherence to regulations. The findings were compiled into a combined M&E report, detailing recommendations for maintenance, modifications, and improvements.
epe_description_3: Conducting surveys in live school environments required careful planning to avoid disrupting teaching. This was managed through close coordination with school staff, out-of-hours inspections, and clear communication.

epe_description_1: In 2010 East UK County Council set a target to reduce its carbon footprint across operations by 25% over 5 years. At the same time, setting a Carbon and Energy Reduction Fund (CERF) of ~£15M to achieve it. The project was also in response to the Government’s new Carbon Reduction Commitment (CRC) reporting regime, which required the Council to pay for its carbon footprint.
epe_description_2: I was responsible for establishing the necessary governance, measurement and reporting processes for the client to ensure full compliance with the CRC Scheme. I provided a client-side technical advisory role to lead and provide oversight to deployment of the ~£15M CERF fund across both corporate and school buildings. It also included a strategic building energy audit of County Hall in advance of proposed refurbishment works to the main tower block.
epe_description_3: A particular challenge for the Council was to understand the complexities of the CRC scheme and evidence pack and reporting requirements to ensure legal compliance. My specific role was to distil those requirements to the Council and established a detailed set of quality procedures, checklist and digital evidence pack repository for the relevant information. This was audited by the Council’s compliance team and externally by the Environment Agency without any recorded non-compliance.

epe_description_1: Between 2014-2016, the Nordwick Group invested ~£20M in renewable energy schemes to generate long term sustainable income to the Business. This investment was undertaken under a new business entity called Nordwick Energy.
epe_description_2: During the development stage, I fulfilled the role as Project Director to a number of schemes to ensure they were successfully delivered from feasibility, financial assessment, design, procurement and installation into operation. Since 2019 - present I fulfilled role as Operations Director, setting annual business plan, commissioning operation and maintenance activities and measuring performance alongside other technical and advisory duties.
epe_description_3: At the outset of the investment, the challenge was to understand the technical and information requirements that were needed to ensure compliance with Ofgem’s Feed in Tariff (FIT) and Renewable Heat Incentive (RHI) regimes so that applications for registration could be made in a timely manner to maximise future return on investment. A Technical Administrator was employed to support this process.

epe_description_1: In 2023,Nordwick Consulting were commissioned by (private firm), through its retained consultant (private firm), to undertake a decarbonisation feasibility study across a number of buildings on the hospital estate. This supported private firm's Outline Business Case to inform retention or disposal as part of the new future Hospital redevelopment.
epe_description_2: I led the project and undertook a proportion of decarbonisation feasibility studies for 9 operational buildings and residential accommodation. I was responsible for developing Heat Decarbonisation Plans, in accordance with Salix funding requirements to support the Outline Business Case for the new (private firm) Development, and carried out option appraisals for standalone low carbon heating systems or connection to the new hospital energy centre where appropriate.
epe_description_3: One of the challenges with this project was to undertake the M&E and building surveys within a live working hospital environment. At the outset of the project we established all points of liaison and surveys were arranged at the appropriate time to avoid any disruption to patients, staff and visitors.

epe_description_1: The town Pavilion, part of the historic Gardens in the county, is a beautifully restored Victorian building originally opened in 1871. Now Grade II-listed, it houses a conservatory, art gallery, retail spaces, and the grand Hall. On this site, this project entails a full renewal of the site's main heating system, including refurbishment of the existing ventilation plant, which has reached the end of its operational life. The selected location for the heating plant will require substantial construction efforts, including significant drainage upgrades and the establishment of compliant access to the basement, again recognising the limitations introduced by the Grade II listing. The design is currently progressing assertively into Stage 4.
epe_description_2: As Project Manager, I oversee the design stages, ensuring roles are clearly defined, the project scope is met, budgets are strictly managed, risks are promptly identified and addressed, and stakeholder communication is consistently maintained.
epe_description_3: Given the building's Grade II listing, it was essential to minimise heritage impact to secure Listed Building Consent while ensuring the solution effectively meets the site's operational requirements. This has been achieved by appointing experienced consultants to the project versed in traditional buildings to oversee the design development in addition to undergoing pragmatic design options appraisals and regular stakeholder meetings with the Local Planning Authority and Conservation Officers.

epe_description_1: Performed BS EN 16247-compliant energy audits for mechanically complex public sector buildings, typically funded by LCSF, preluding PSDS funding schemes.
epe_description_2: I was responsible for delivering building-specific decarbonisation plans as technical reports. This enabled the team to understand the viability of introducing clean/renewable technologies (demand reduction, smarter buildings, renewable generation, and decarbonising heat) and their associated costs and savings. It was then presented to clients and stakeholders as required. Audits include holistic assessments on M+E services and building fabric to identify opportunities to retrofit improvements and any required enabling works.
epe_description_3: The types of buildings that have undergone detailed technical audits vary from simple commercial sites to large complex buildings used within a health service capacity. Thus, the solutions vary dramatically reflective of the building’s operational needs. For large sites in relatively close proximity to others, we have also reviewed the opportunities to install large heat network solutions. To reach net zero, any use of fossil fuels must be removed, which is the mentality adopted within our approach to deliver the works. Thus, we always deliver Net Zero operational carbon solutions.

epe_description_1: Collate and analyse energy consumption from the client’s entire estate portfolio by maintaining their Energy Management System. We also monitored and reported their energy and carbon performance to track annual progress against the Council’s carbon reduction strategies. Our service also included energy audits of poor performing properties identified from the consumption profiling activities.
epe_description_2: Delivered energy and carbon management services for a County Council's corporate and school estate, focusing on their estate compliance, carbon inventories, energy performance monitoring, and decarbonisation strategies. Energy management systems (eSight) were used to transpose and record utilities, meters, and respective energy consumption from their suppliers. Supported year-on-year energy/carbon reductions through estate management and capital investment planning by incorporating the analysed data.
epe_description_3: Key achievements include analysing large datasets to identify priority assets as a ‘strategic estate-wide decarbonisation plan’, surveying and costing £1m in capital investments and retrofits, enabling design and construction projects to begin Net Zero and decarbonisation transition at these sites.  Why did the client want this service to be delivered.

epe_description_1: A new build development of 67 properties with a mix of tenures 2 bed social housing to 5 bed luxury spec detached properties with extended grounds and a very high individual specification.
epe_description_2: Lead Site Manager for the whole development with day-to-day control of all operations on site, health and safety, ordering materials, organising labour, hitting programme days and delivering a quality product and outcome. The result was to leave a fully completed new estate of housing and public open spaces.
epe_description_3:
The development was a challenging project to deliver with the need for extensive storm water attenuation controls needed in the form of underground tanks and reduced flow discharge controls. 
The specification on the signature properties was extensive and very high with many additional extras not normally seen in domestic properties, surround sound throughout properties, extensive surveillance, keyless entry systems - gates – property access doors, underground parking, lifts to all floors and swimming pools.

epe_description_1: New build development of 75 Properties on a demanding sloping site with limited access through an existing estate. I was involved in this development from initial ground clearance and investigation to handover of the final property to its new owner.
epe_description_2: Responsible for all aspects of the development’s delivery, health and safety, instructing subcontractors, checking works, ordering materials, keeping accurate records and reporting progress to ensure a high quality of works were produced.
epe_description_3: The development was only accessible through a completed estate road. And on a steeply sloping site with drainage being a major obstacle as a live railway line was beyond the bottom boundary of the development. This required permanent engineering solutions including pumped foul sewer chamber and additional storm water collection and controlled release infrastructure being built. Additionally due to the restricted access through an existing housing estate the need to carefully control and co-ordinate materials deliveries and neighbour relations was paramount in dealing with all parties.

epe_description_1: This is a two-storey standalone expansion to an existing Academy, incorporating a sports hall and a stepped flat roof with parapet. The superstructure is a steel frame with an in-situ concrete composite deck forming the floors and main roof, utilising composite action with the primary steels designed and detailed in accordance with disproportionate collapse requirements set out in Building Regulations Part A3 for a Category 2b building. The sports hall roof is a structural metal deck. Translucent proprietary danpatherm cladding has been used alongside bricks and brick slip panels. The substructure is traditional strip and pad foundation system, deepening towards the adjacent trees to the west side of the building. A suspended precast concrete beam and block ground floor has been used throughout.
epe_description_2: I took over the project from stage three onwards and was the Lead Structural Engineer carrying out design calculations and drawings for the project.
epe_description_3: Limited headroom for the floor construction dictated the use of composite design. Several iterations of analysis, including floor vibration assessments were carried out to create efficiencies make best use of the space available. This negated the need to raise the building height, thus keeping costs and embodied carbon down. The novel proprietary danpatherm cladding, combined with traditional masonry and brick slip panels throughout the external envelope required precise coordination between disciplines.

epe_description_1: This is a two-storey, with small single storey area, proposed 2fe primary school in the area with full height sports hall. Roofs are flat. There is a colonnade on the Southern elevation of the building. The superstructure is a braced steel frame with precast concrete planks, designed and detailed in accordance with disproportionate collapse requirements set out in Building Regulations Part A for a Category 2b building. The substructure is piled with reinforced concrete ground beam foundations throughout the whole building, with suspended precast concrete beam and block ground floor throughout. The development includes a retaining wall to the Western boundary of the site.
epe_description_2: I was the Lead Structural Engineer from Concept through Detailed Design and am to continue this during Construction, carrying out design calculations and drawings for the project as well as liaising with the Contractor during construction.
epe_description_3: Original geotechnical investigations indicated traditional shallow foundations would be suitable for the site but also highlighted a ‘soft spot’ within the footprint. To determine the extents of the ‘soft spot’ over the site I requested additional geotechnical investigations to be conducted, including plate load testing and additional dynamic probes. The additional investigations indicated the ‘soft spot’ had greater extents than previously thought and recommended an engineered foundation system. This required a full re-design of the foundation system to a piled solution.

epe_description_1: This is a large special educational needs (SEN) school in the county, with three-storey, two-storey and single-storey areas, with a mixture of pitched and flat roofs. The building includes an attached dining hall and sports hall. The superstructure is a steel frame with precast concrete planks, designed and detailed in accordance with disproportionate collapse requirements set out in Building Regulations Part A for a Category 2b building. Due to the length of the building a structural movement joint was included where the building changes angle on plan. The substructure is a CFA (Continuous Flight Auger) pile and reinforced concrete ground beam foundation solution under the three-storey area and traditional strip and pad foundations elsewhere, with suspended precast concrete beam and block ground floor throughout. External works include a reinforced concrete and masonry retaining walls.
epe_description_2: I worked in conjunction with the Lead Structural Engineer to produce detailed design drawings and calculations from stage 3 onwards as well as liaising with the Contractor during construction.
epe_description_3: Due to the length and angle change of the building a movement joint was required through the primary structure. Complex structural detailing was carried out with coordination from other disciplines to enable construction and allow both sides of the building to expand and contract without a build-up of stresses. To reduce the impact on costs and minimise embodied carbon, the foundation solution also varied across the building, using the movement joint as a natural division. The three-storey area was piled, with reinforced ground beams, and the remaining areas constructed on traditional pad and strip footings. At the interface, dowelled joints have been used to minimise differential settlement.

epe_description_1: This residential project spans multiple sites and includes a mix of bungalows, houses, and flats. All buildings feature traditional masonry superstructures. The houses incorporate timber first floors, while the flats use precast concrete. Timber roof trusses were used consistently across all building types and locations. The substructure consists of traditional strip foundations, stepped where necessary due to nearby trees and cohesive soils—and a suspended precast concrete beam and block floor system.
epe_description_2: Initially design services were provided up to stage 4 for a traditional procurement type. Following stage 4 the client indicated they would like to explore design and build procurement. Following this, I undertook a technical advisor role. As a technical advisor I wrote employers’ requirement documents, reviewed contractor proposals ensuring these met the employers’ requirements and appropriate standards and liaised with the client and contractors regarding these.
epe_description_3: The client’s decision late into stage 4 to change procurement following design work already being undertaken for a traditional contract required a change of approach and mindset towards the project. This shift introduced new challenges but also provided an opportunity to reassess delivery strategies, ensuring alignment with the revised procurement route and maintaining project momentum.

epe_description_1: This Academy is a modern secondary school in the area, focused on academic excellence, student development, and strong community engagement. This project is two single-storey additional blocks to a high school and internal remodelling of some of the existing school. The two new blocks are a standalone CDT block and an extension to the dining hall. The superstructure of the proposed new buildings is steel frame, with metal deck roofs. The substructure is CFA (continuous flight auger) piles, with a RC floor slab.
epe_description_2: I was lead structural engineer on the internal remodelling works from stage 4 and have picked up the on-site construction lead for the new build blocks from stage 5.
epe_description_3: Due to the King’s Lynn Site having a potential flood risk, and ground gas present, the design for the new build blocks had to incorporate flood resistant construction and sufficient gas protection measures. By accurately and promptly co-ordinating the design information with other disciplines (Civil, Architectural, Mechanical etc), we have been able to provide the client with a building that complies with local flooding and gas protection measures without having to remediate on site, which could be complicated and costly.

epe_description_1: This Academy is a high-achieving secondary school in the area, catering to students aged 11 to 16. This project involves internally remodelling of three blocks. The science block remodelling involved installation of a new steel frame to allow for removal of internal loadbearing, masonry shear walls. Lateral stability is provided via a provision of steel, moment-resisting picture frames. The music block remodelling involved provision of new lintels for openings. The library block remodelling involves new lintels, and provision of new external ramp structure.
epe_description_2: I am lead structural engineer since the start of Stage 2.
epe_description_3: Due to a lack of structural archive information, the behaviour of the existing science block structure was unclear. However, by undertaking some visual and intrusive structural inspections of the substructure and superstructure, I was able to confidently reduce the scope of the required structural work, saving the client both money and time on site.

epe_description_1: This School is a specialist school in the county for students aged 3 to 19 with complex learning needs. It provides a nurturing, inclusive environment tailored to individual abilities, offering a broad and engaging curriculum that supports academic, social, and life skills development, helping every student reach their full potential. This project involved design of a new build teaching block and hydrotherapy block at the School. The superstructure of both blocks was to be timber framed, with a timber roof. The substructure was to be a RC raft foundation. Lateral stability was to be provided via the provision of timber racking walls.
epe_description_2: I was lead structural engineer at Stage 2, responsible for concept design and compilation of the structural drawing package.
epe_description_3: The site had very low soil bearing capacity, necessitating the use of an engineered foundation, such as piles or a raft. By designing the substructure as an engineered raft foundation, rather than piles, it was possibly to reduce the overall embodied carbon of the project, which we able to positively report to the client. A raft foundation was also more cost effective for the client than a piled foundation in terms of labour and material costs as well as the ease of incorporating the hydrotherapy pool structure. The Hydrotherapy Pool substructure had to be designed to resist the aggressive chemical environment of a pool, to the requirements of BS8007 – Standard for Cide of Practice for Design of Concrete Structures for Retaining Aqueous Liquids and Eurocode 2 – Design of Concrete Structures.

epe_description_1: Relocation of plant nursery services to new state of the art horticultural glasshouse. The Arium is the biggest plant nursery in the cite and one of a kind as it grows all plants on-site in four temperature-controlled growing zones.
epe_description_2: Quantity Surveyor throughout. Tendered including Dutch consortium and specialist materials from Europe around Brexit.
epe_description_3: Winner of a Community award in 2018.

epe_description_1: The project involved all aspects of constructing a new large housing project. This included ground clearance, bring services onto and around the development, constructing a new electrical substation and major gas monitor station to new deep drainage and connections to mains and the introduction of storm water swales and attenuation tanks for storm water control. Beyond this, the project included constructing new estate roads, public open spaces and playgrounds. I was involved in all areas of this project from clearing the existing ground to completion took approximately four years of daily involvement.
epe_description_2: Senior site manager with daily control of project to deliver 350no - new build properties including 10no - 3 and 4 story blocks of 2 bed apartments and 250no 2 / 3- and 4-bedroom newbuild houses / terraces / semi / detached.
epe_description_3: The construction phase was programmed to ensure the new residents were safe and segregated from ongoing works. I led all material and labour requirements by controlling the build programme in line with Co policies and expectations. This was a major new housing development near to the centre of Doncaster. In effect building a new community from disused land, including all required infrastructure, roads, public open spaces, swales and street lighting. Social value was a major factor in the project delivery as we saw the employment of local people and engaging with the surrounding existing local community by distributing newsletters, having progress meetings with existing adjacent residents, visiting local schools, having school children visit the site, sponsoring local charities and using local businesses and local suppliers if possible, to bring additional local value to the project.

epe_description_1: This project involved the demolition of the existing structures and formation of a new main entrance to the city train statiomn with the inclusion of cycle hubs which will include electric charging and storage of cycles, members area and new entrance steps, 2 X 21 passenger lifts and pedestrianising areas with a new taxi rank facility being relocated. The scheme also involved the upgrading of roads and footpaths around the area of the main works creating cycle paths and pedestrian areas.
epe_description_2: COWs inspections for the building elements of the project including the steel frame and facade for the new entrance, new toilet and changing facilities, cladding to the dark arches and adjacent streets to the main works
epe_description_3: The demolition and construction has been programmed to ensure that all members of the public using both the ongoing train services and road routes still in use around the site in the city centre location are segregated from the ongoing works, beyond the immediate works has been a program of upgrading roads, footpaths, and creating new cycleways which involved close liaison with all stakeholders including hotels restaurants shops and bars, along with existing taxi provisions. The works to a Mill which has some listed features created a challenging design to deliver the space required for the purpose intended including extensive waterproofing of existing and new elements of the construction.

epe_description_1: A new development of single storey houses, along with 3 and 4 storey apartments for the social housing sector. The project involved all aspects of constructing a new large housing project. This included ground clearance, bringing new services onto and around the development, some solar panels were included within the design on the new apartment blocks to supplement landlords power usage. New deep drainage and connections to the existing mains and the introduction of storm water attenuation tanks which was controlled by a flow control system designed to prevent over charging of the existing drainage system. Off road car parking and electric car charging was included for both the apartments and houses as part of the design.
epe_description_2: I was involved in all areas of this project from clearing the existing ground to completion took approximately 2 years of weekly inspection visits. Duties included weekly inspections during the build process through to completion to ensure that the units were built in accordance with the drawings and specification requirements up to handover of the project and 12 months defects inspection up to issuing the defects certificate.
epe_description_3: The construction phase was programmed to ensure the existing residents were safe and segregated from ongoing works. This was a major new housing development in an already highly populated area of the city with its own social challenges. There was ongoing social engagement with the surrounding existing local community by distributing newsletters, and using local businesses and local suppliers, if possible, to bring additional local value to the project.

epe_description_1: The project comprised the construction of 16 Nr new build semi-detached properties and all associated external works and services on a landlocked infill site with poor site access. The construction utilised timber frame with an external masonry envelope and innovative ground source heat pump technology to provide heating for the houses supplemented by solar panels to the roofs. Individual and collective storm water attenuation was included within the design with new deep foul drainage connecting to the existing system. Off road car parking and electric car charging was included for both the apartments and houses as part of the design The project was delayed because of the construction of a retaining wall and boundary dispute which required notices to be served under the Party Wall Act 1996. Similarly, the presence of Japanese Knotweed adjacent to an existing Public Right of Way prohibited the contractual works to improve the footpath from being undertaken.
epe_description_2: Duties include weekly inspections during the build process through to completion to ensure that the units were built in accordance with the drawings and specification requirements up to handover of the project and 12 months defects inspection up to issuing the defects certificate.
epe_description_3: The construction phase was programmed to ensure the existing residents were safe and segregated from ongoing works. The access to the site was a single road which made the logistics of deliveries of all building materials challenging whilst trying to maintain access/egress for the residents along the route to the development There was ongoing social engagement with the surrounding existing local community by distributing newsletters, and using local businesses and local suppliers, if possible, to bring additional local value to the project.

epe_description_1: The project comprised the construction of 12 Nr new build semi-detached properties and all associated external works and services on a landlocked infill site with poor site access. The construction utilised timber frame with an external masonry envelope and innovative ground source heat pump technology to provide heating for the houses supplemented by solar panels to the roofs. Individual and collective storm water attenuation was included within the design with new deep foul drainage connecting to the existing system. Off road car parking and electric car charging was included for both the apartments and houses as part of the design The project was delayed significantly due to the constrained nature of the site. The site also included a new public open space to provide residents and the local community with an area of mutual natural use.
epe_description_2: Duties include weekly inspections during the build process through to completion to ensure that the units were built in accordance with the drawings and specification requirements up to handover of the project and 12 months defects inspection up to issuing the defects certificate.
epe_description_3: The construction phase was programmed to ensure the existing residents were safe and segregated from ongoing works. The access to the site was along an already highly populated route which made the logistics of deliveries of all building materials challenging whilst trying to maintain access/egress for the residents along the route to the development There was ongoing social engagement with the surrounding existing local community by distributing newsletters, and using local businesses and local suppliers if possible, to bring additional local value to the project.

epe_description_1: School expansion was phased from demolition of existing buildings and construction of new school, to allow the existing school to remain operational throughout the build process. The building included the provision of new MUGA and football pitches on the site of the old school which provides a stream of income and use by residents out of school hours. The new development included new gas, electric and water mains services and the construction of a new electrical substation on the site of the new car park and bus turning hub adjacent to the school, new deep drainage and storm water attenuation was installed to prevent over charging of the existing system by means of a flow control chamber designed into the system. The new facility included teaching facilities for both practical and technical studies including science and woodwork classes to ensure a spread of learning for all student capabilities
epe_description_2: Duties include weekly inspections during the build process through to completion to ensure that the units were built in accordance with the drawings and specification requirements up to handover of the project and 12 months defects inspection up to issuing the defects certificate.
epe_description_3: The construction phase was programmed to ensure the existing residents were safe and segregated from ongoing works. This was a major new school development in an already highly populated area of Leeds alongside a major busy road. The contract required maintaining the road and pedestrian routes to the school to allow pupils to access the school both on foot and by the bus services provided. There was ongoing social engagement with the surrounding existing local community by distributing newsletters, and using local businesses and local suppliers, if possible, to bring additional local value to the project.

epe_description_1: The new construction of a multi-use care home including dementia care, from demolition of existing buildings and construction of new care home. The new development included new gas, electric and water mains services and new deep drainage, storm water attenuation was installed to prevent over charging of the existing system by means of a flow control chamber designed into the system. The new facility was designed to accommodate dementia residents which included alarms to prevent vulnerable residents from unintentional egress from the facility to ensure their safety. The new care home linked to an existing care home as part of the completed design which was in full use during the construction phase.
epe_description_2: Duties included weekly inspections during the build process through to completion to ensure that the units were built in accordance with the drawings and specification requirements up to handover of the project and 12 months defects inspection up to issuing the defects certificate.
epe_description_3: The construction phase was programmed to ensure the existing residents were safe and segregated from ongoing works. This was a major new care facility development in an already highly populated area of the city in the middle of a housing estate adjacent to an existing care home. The contract required maintaining the road and pedestrian routes to the residents of adjacent houses and care home. There was ongoing social engagement with the surrounding existing local community by distributing newsletters, and using local businesses and local suppliers, if possible, to bring additional local value to the project.

epe_description_1: This project provides an 80-place extension to the School, to deliver critical ‘Special Educational Needs’ pupil places on behalf of the City Council. The expansion is primarily a 1,900m2 extension to the existing school building, arranged as a two storey ancillary block, a central circulation core, a three-storey main teaching block, and a warm ‘link’ building connecting the extension to the existing school.
epe_description_2: In my role as overseeing Team Leader and CDM Principal Designer (up to RIBA Stage 3), I assisted the project architects to navigate key risks and constraints, including the retention of a number of mature trees and public sewer easement directly adjacent the new building, and phasing in such a way as to minimise disruption to the operations of a live SEN school.
epe_description_3: The link building involved challenging building fabric and structural interfaces, such as bridging the Tubosider drainage system, maintaining adequate ventilation and daylight to existing teaching spaces. The key to resolving these issues was to ensure landlocked classrooms could benefit from borrowed light by maximising glazing to the link atrium and introduce a sensitively designed mechanical ventilation system.

epe_description_1: Nordwick was commissioned to remodel, refurbish and complete a Category B fit out of this outdated 1980s office accommodation. Our brief was to establish the optimum number of workstations spread over five floors to accommodate 874 staff using flexible working solutions. We established that the optimum number of workstations was 524, and the design included the provision of meeting suites to accommodate varying numbers on the ground floor.
epe_description_2: Our role within this project was to provide full design services. The Nordwick team provided full interior architectural design, project management, mechanical and electrical design, IT infrastructure design, CDMC, quantity surveying and quality management. The design element also included liaising with client subcontractors for IT equipment installations, FFE installation and security systems installation. I provided lead architect and project lead services, working closely with the interior designer and other disciplines to ensure a co-ordinated and technically feasible approach.
epe_description_3: It was essential to address accessibility issues, so we relocated the entrance to the building to provide wheelchair access and more space for the reception. More accessible lifts and WC facilities were provided by remodelling around the centre core of the building. Measures to minimise environmental impact included providing adequate bike storage and a shower block for cyclist and runners, to encourage more people to use sustainable methods of commuting. Successfully achieving a complex phased occupation of the building tested the team but these issues were overcome by working closely with the city council's in-house contractor and a number of key sub-contractors alongside the Client over the phasing period.

epe_description_1: The scheme involved the expansion of a Primary School from 1 Form Entry to 2 Form Entry (210 pupils to 410 pupils) to meet the requirements of the City Council Children’s Services and school pupil place criteria. The development comprised of a new two-storey, six classroom new build (Block 1) and refurbishment and small expansion of the existing nursery and reception class space, including additional WCs for staff and pupils. A new ramp area was built and draining reconfigured by Block 2. The development also incorporated a new multi-use games area, improved car parking space for staff incorporating disabled car park spaces, new bin store and bike rack space, improved pedestrian area and a new central habitat space forming the focus of the courtyard design with planting and seating to be enjoyed by staff and pupils alike.
epe_description_2: Provided lead architectural services from RIBA Stages 2-6, prepared statutory applications, co-ordinated the multi-disciplinary team and acted as key client contact.
epe_description_3: The site was steeply sloping with high levels of ground gas, therefore the groundworks package was complex, but the design solution was well-considered.

epe_description_1: We were commissioned to undertake a multi-disciplinary design and delivery of a new two form entry, and 26 nursery place Primary School based at the site of the former city Sports Centre. The school has been landscaped with a multi-use games area, as well as soft play and habitat areas. The brise soleil at the rear of the school provides an architectural feature which reduces heat gain within the building by filtering direct sunlight on the southern façade, whilst forming shaded teaching areas flowing from the ground floor classrooms.
epe_description_2: Provided lead architectural services from RIBA Stages 1-3B co-ordinating the multi-disciplinary team and planning application. Then acted as lead client technical advisor on site as the contractor delivered under a D&B procurement with their design team.
epe_description_3: The proximity of the school to the motorway presented significant acoustic issues which were overcome by our specialist mechanical and electrical engineering team who designed a natural ventilation system using façade and roof mounted units. Brick fin walls act as a sound barrier from the adjacent motorway, enabling a passive ventilation strategy using opening windows, whilst maintaining ambient noise at reasonable levels in the teaching spaces.

epe_description_1: The project involved the construction of a specialist high ropes course and new modular office.
epe_description_2: Provided Quantity Surveying duties on behalf of the Main Contractor appointed for the works. This involved procurement of sub-contractors, and modular cabin, management of variations, final accounts and managing the contractors design element for the works. This was delivered through to client handover.
epe_description_3: This project was particularly challenging due to the various contractor’s design proportions may of which overlapped with the clients design, this meant a lot of the design had to be done hand in hand with the client team which often resulted in various delays. To overcome this issue, we had regular design team meeting, where we could collaboratively find solutions to the problems whilst also mitigating as many delays to the programme as possible.

epe_description_1: A refurbishment of an existing building into an event space.
epe_description_2: Provided Quantity Surveying duties on behalf of the Main Contractor appointed for the works with the lead senior quantity surveyor. This involved procurement of sub-contractors, management of variations and instructions, final accounts and assisting the contractors design element for the works
epe_description_3: This project was another challenging one to deliver as we were working on a live holiday park site, during one of their peak holiday seasons. Due to weather and various start on site issues the client was already several weeks behind their anticipated completion date. To solve this issue, we firstly implemented a rigorous site boundary to prevent any issues with the public. We also worked with the client to offer both value and time saving options to help accelerate the programme. Through this we delivered the course on time for the client.

epe_description_1: Demolition of the existing council estate and the construction of 4 new build residential blocks comprising of 120 affordable rent units inclusive of soft and hard landscaping and a district heating network.
epe_description_2: I led the design team as the PM from inception (stage 1-3) securing planning and procurement of the main contractor. From stages 4 onwards my role was PM and Employer’s Agent, whereby I administered the contract on behalf of the client.
epe_description_3: The client required us to get into contract within 8-9 months from our commission which meant we had circa 5/6 months to complete stages 1-3 on a medium-large project and submit to planning; this required running parallel programmes to meet milestones. This was to secure the GLA funding and ensure financial viability of the scheme.

epe_description_1: New Build Construction of 3 small residential sites utilising vacant garage locations within the borough.
epe_description_2: Assistant PM from 2018 onwards - helping the lead PM/Employer’s Agent throughout stage 4-6.
epe_description_3: All 3 contracts had significant EoT claims due to the discovery of asbestos (in 2) and the stability of the ground in another which required an engineered bank.

epe_description_1: A Leisure Centre underwent a major £2.5 million refurbishment which was completed in January 2025. Part of the project included the overseeing of the removal of RAAC. Supply and install new roofs and M&E and refurbish to parts of the Leisure centre. The result was that the project delivered extensive internal upgrades, including refreshed swimming pool facilities, new lighting, and modernised reception and meeting areas.
epe_description_2: It was my responsibility to take the project from inception to final account.
epe_description_3: The Leisure Centre remained in operation throughout the project which was a real challenge. We had to close sections of the Leisure Centre at various times to allow works to progress. All works were programmed in advance with the Leisure Centre. Keeping the Leisure centre open helped keep member numbers steady throughout the project.

epe_description_1: This Housing is a residential development located in the area, delivered by the local authority. The project saw the development of a new build 5 storey blocks of flats containing 42 units arranged around a landscaped courtyard, with terraces that re-establish street frontage and integrate communal gardens and play areas. This development formed part of a wider regeneration initiative, helping fund new purpose-built respite care and therapy facilities nearby.
epe_description_2: To take the project from inception through to final account and negotiate the claim for an extension of time and deed of variation.

It is my role to keep financial control over the five MTC contracts which are General Building Repairs, Mechanical and Electrical, Water hygiene, FRA and Asbestos that we have in place at present. Monthly spend trackers, checking of estimate, agreeing final accounts., Quarterly meetings. These contracts cover Education and some corporate buildings.
epe_description_3: Keeping on top of all the estimates an keeping the clients aware of all that is happening.

epe_description_1: The project involved the construction of a new build education block an addition within the existing school site. The building compromised of a two-storey building, with classrooms, group rooms, welfare facility and office areas. The new classroom building is independent to the existing main building.
epe_description_2: Responsible for delivering mechanical services design through RIBA stages 0 – 3, and then review of design and build information issued by contractor RIBA stages 4-6
epe_description_3: Key challenges were meeting tight deadline and budget. To meet these challenges it was important to liaise with the design team regularly, understand clients’ requirements and carry out design to meet the brief and budget. Once a contractor was appointed it was important the client brief was followed through, and requirements met. Once on-site regular site meetings were held, liaising with contractor on a regular basis, carrying out any actions promptly and keeping the client well informed. It was important to make sure design and construction requirements were met through the stages to manage costs and minimise variations and complete the project on time and within budget.

epe_description_1: The project involved the construction of a new build education provision facility to compromise a High Needs Centre for secondary age pupils and a Family Resilience Centre to act as an out-reach hub to provide support to families. The building compromised of a two-storey building, with classrooms, group rooms, large kitchen facility and dining area, WC areas, gym / hall area, and general office and meeting rooms. The site also included play and amenity area at the rear of the site.
epe_description_2: Responsible for delivering mechanical services design through RIBA stages 0 – 3, and then review of design and build information issued by contractor RIBA stages 4-6
epe_description_3: Key challenges were meeting the requirements of two separates tenants within the same building. Also, meeting tight deadline and budget. Having separate tenants, it was important to understand each tenant requirements. Regular design team meetings were held keeping the client well informed of progress to meet deadlines and to keep design within budget. Progress reports provided to ensure client remained updated through the design and construction stage.

epe_description_1: Woking on the UK development – UK Hotel Building. This project compromised of plant areas, a lobby area, LV Switchrooms and a further 17 floors of hotel occupying floors. In addition to the 190 hotel guest rooms, hotel facilities included a ballroom, bar, restaurant, and café facilities as well as conference and meeting rooms and a gym.
epe_description_2: Responsible for delivering mechanical services design through RIBA stages 3 – 4.
epe_description_3: Key challenges were meeting tight deadline and coordination of a vast array of M&E services due to the nature of the building type and project. Dealing with numerous design team members, manufacturer, and stake holders. To meet these challenges, it was vital to provide clear and concise communication with design team members and stake holders, keeping everyone well informed. Regular design and coordination meetings were important to manage progress, deadlines, actions and to highlight any potential risks that could have an impact on project cost or completion.

epe_description_1: Increase from 6FE to 8FE secondary school, works included new science block, new performance hall, extension to English block, refurbishment of hall, new MUGA and external play areas.
epe_description_2: Project Manager & Employers Agent On a tight school site the works had to be phased with 14 sectional completions across the enabling works and main works contracts.

epe_description_1: A new build care village catering for 100 housing with care residents with extra care including a Dementia Care Unit for 80 residents. The project involved specialised FF&E specifications to ensure a sensitive and safe environment is provided for those residents suffering with dementia whilst maintaining a homely and non-institutional feel.
epe_description_2: I led the FFE and Interior Design elements of the project including the procurement process ensuring the FF&E packages were approved and satisfied the requirements of the authority's internal procurement standards.
epe_description_3: The design for this care village was a culmination of research and development gained through the design team having specialist training on designing for residents suffering with Dementia. This was undertaken with REMOVED-NAME University’s specialist Dementia Services Development Centre and they supported the team with design audits throughout the process to ensure the clients brief was met ‘providing a state of the art facility to support those living with and suffering from Dementia’. REMOVED-NAME Care Village was highly commended at the UK Healthcare Awards.

epe_description_1: This School, located in the county, is a co-educational secondary school known for its inclusive ethos and commitment to academic excellence. To meet growing demand, the school is undergoing a 1FE (one form of entry) expansion which includes a new double-height extension to the existing hall which will provide an additional 350m² of hall area, along with a two-storey extension featuring a rooftop play area.
epe_description_2: Cost Estimation, Tendering and Contracts, Cost control and Management from start to finish.
epe_description_3: The double-height extension was delayed by 43 weeks due to planning requirements to preserve a willow tree located within 6 metres of the new extension. As part of the project team we kept the client fully informed about the programme and cost implications

epe_description_1: This Grade II* listed mansion built around 1745 on the edge of the county, is regarded as one of the finest and least altered examples of Georgian domestic architecture in the area. Since 2008, the building has remained largely unused and has suffered from neglect. It now requires significant restoration to secure its long-term future and to be removed from Historic England’s Heritage at Risk register.
epe_description_2: Cost Estimation, Tendering and Contracts, Cost control and Management from start to finish.
epe_description_3: A significant challenge was undertaking the project with a constrained budget. I supported the client through this by maintaining a regular and prompt cost agreement process with the contractor to address unforeseen works arising during the restoration and repair of the historic building. All additional works were carefully assessed to ensure full compliance with conservation requirements. We worked closely with the Contract Administrator (CA) to implement change order requests efficiently, ensuring transparency and control over project variations.

epe_service: Building Surveyor, Designer, CA and PM
epe_description_1: REMOVED-NAME Residential Care Home is a circa 40-bedroom care home providing care to elderly residents. The project involved refurbishment and alterations works to an existing Care Home to form 5no. En-Suite bedrooms, Shower Room, ancillary spaces and refurbishment of existing Corridors. The project value was circa £207,000.
epe_description_2: Building Surveying services to include design and specification, contract administration and project managements services from inception through to completion. Works included management of Structural Engineering designers, obtaining Building Regulations approvals and managing asbestos removals.
