epe_description_3: The works were split into two distinct phases, and were also delivered around the operational needs of the Care Home. This required very careful logistical planning with careful liaison maintained between the Home and Principal Contractor. The project was delivered on programme and within budget.

epe_description_1: East UK City Council 1 School 2 expansion from 1FE to 2FE through significant remodelling, alteration and extension works to the existing 1FE school building. Acting as Project Manager and Employer’s Agent for the planning, procurement and construction of the project from RIBA Stage 2 to 6.
epe_description_2: Project Manager and Employer’s Agent services for the project throughout RIBA Stages 2-6, liaising with all stakeholders as necessary to ensure the successful delivery of the project.
epe_description_3: The project was delivered in two main phases to include construction of an 8-classroom new-build extension, with the second phase to include complete remodelling and refurbishment of the original school building. There were significant phasing and logistical challenges during the delivery of the project to ensure construction was safely delivered around the operational needs of the school. This included managing a full decant of the original school building into the new extension at the mid-point of the project.

epe_description_1: Work on the major city road started in 2018, with the aim of reducing congestion and improve traffic flow on the busy road. Works included the widening of the existing road network between junctions.
epe_description_2: Lead designer for the widening works (to 4 lanes of traffic, including a dedicated shared-use facility) which involved diversion of a High-Pressure Gas Main and national importance fibre-optics. The removal of trees with Tree Protection Orders (TPO), Bat and Arboriculture Surveys and land transfers.
epe_description_3: The overall project was challenging due to the location of the works on one of counties strategic road networks. The road had historical drainage issues, alongside the need to divert the High-Pressure gas main and nationally important fibre-optic cables as they connected all of the counties Governance and Banking systems with Europe.

epe_description_1: Town centre improvements to benefit all users (car, bus, bike and pedestrian), regeneration of the town centre to encourage growth and investment, projects involved junction re-alignments, pedestrian improvements, car park re-alignment, new pedestrian footpaths and community spaces.
epe_description_2: Lead designer for the car park scheme and assistant designer on all other sub-projects, my involvement was from concept to inception which included everything from design drawings, meetings with stakeholders and contractors, contract documentation, health and safety file, tender and construction management.
epe_description_3: The project presented significant challenges due to its location in a busy town centre. It was essential to design with sensitivity to the surrounding environment, ensuring construction could proceed with minimal disruption to local businesses and residents, allowing the town’s daily life to continue smoothly throughout the build.

epe_description_1: In a town in the county, a £3.4 million programme was designed to regenerate the old commercial heart of the historic town. This included town centre improvements which would benefit all users (car, bus, bike and pedestrian), and encourage growth and investment. The project involved junction re-alignments, improvements to pedestrian areas, promotion of a Café culture, community space improvements and Traffic Regulation Orders.
epe_description_2: I assistant designer and lead designer (due to long term sickness of lead) the overall project, heading up the design and construction of the infrastructure elements, working directly with the client from concept to inception. I worked alongside other designers and architects to include improvements and restoration to the Grade II Listed Hall and community spaces.
epe_description_3: The overall project was extremely challenging. Due to its location, it was important to consider business owners and residents during the construction process while designing my project to ensure it could be built while the life of the town continued around the projects.

epe_description_1: The need for a major county bypass was first discussed in 1937, with local residents starting campaigns for it in the late 1990s. The road will be nearly 4km in length once built with roundabouts and bridges, alongside this an advanced drainage scheme will be delivered to both alleviate the recent floods in the area and to capture surface water from the bypass and its surrounding proposed development.
epe_description_2: Design Review, Developing Legal Orders (Side Road Order and Traffic Regulation Orders), Signage Design, Walking, Cycling and Horse-riding Assessment and Review (WCHAR), Accessibility Assessments, Contract Administration, Archaeological Works Management, Financial Reports, Design Drawing Review, Air Quality and Noise Assessments, Ecological Assessment Review, Arboriculture Assessment Review, Public Rights of Way (PRoW) Design, land purchase agreements and negotiations, section 106 agreements, public consultation events, contract document writing to NEC4 and contractor tendering processes.
epe_description_3: The overall project was extremely challenging, with multiple consultees and designers to consider.

epe_description_1: The project involves the relocation of one of the City Council’s internal services, from its current premises to a new warehouse facility. It is a complex 24/7 service that plays a vital role in supporting discharge from hospital and enables residents (adults and children) to live independently in their own homes. The works comprise; strip and fit out of the Offices and Warehouse – to create additional WC/Showers, Meeting/Training/Wellbeing Rooms plus separate accommodation for the Client’s other services
epe_description_2: Providing NEC4 PM duties from RIBA Stage 5.
epe_description_3: Managing an evolving project team has been challenging and the transfer of project knowledge has at times been difficult. Additionally, managing contractor expectations in relation to delays in contract signing, additional scope items being added, issues pertaining efficient asbestos removal prior to commencement of works have added to challenges on this project. As Project Manager I have worked alongside the Client and wider project team ensuring open and mutually respectful and beneficial discussions have been had to highlight these problems early in the process and deploy steps and actions to mitigate where possible.

epe_description_1: The project involved the construction of a new two-story dining block with survey, dining area and 6 classrooms. In addition, a single-story extension to the science block to create one additional science lab. In addition to the above, we had strict planning conditions to comply with including highways improvements.
epe_description_2: On this project, I was Project Manager from pre-start through to completion.
epe_description_3: The main contractor was unable to fulfil the project 8 months into the scheme. This resulted in terminating of their contract and necessitated the reprocuring of the remaining works. This created an 8-month delay, so as Project Manager I worked closely with the client, supporting progress and managing expectations. Doing this, and supporting the end users, provided the necessary reassurance to all stakeholders.

epe_description_1: Redevelopment of an existing housing area to create 22 new dwellings and refurbished 5 existing dwellings and landscaping. The main objectives were to deliver zero carbon (in-use) design solution, an increased level of quality affordable housing throughout this integrated ‘context led development’ that is inclusive, safe and enjoyable for residents and visitors.
epe_description_2: On this project I acted as consultant project manager for the design team through stages 2 – Stage 3ER’s – including planning approval.
epe_description_3: The main challenge was ensuring we acted with integrity towards the local community. Those directly impacted by the redevelopment were engaged with and supported by our delivery team throughout the design process and planning stages. This was achieved by hosting several community engagement workshops and meetings, public exhibitions and direct engagement with individuals in order that we would listen to concerns, and ally fear and worries. Subsequently, planning was approved with no objections.

epe_description_1: We were commissioned to undertake a stock condition survey on 81 operational buildings by the local Council.  The survey encompassed the inspection of property ranging in size from small lock up facilities at green open spaces to library buildings, the Town Hall and Civic Centre, some of which are grade II listed. Our inspections captured condition data on both building fabric and Mechanical and Electrical components to enable the Council to budget and prioritise planned maintenance to the property portfolio.
epe_description_2: On this project I acted as the main client contact, programme manager and M&E Surveyor.
epe_description_3: As with any condition survey programme, the biggest challenge is arranging unrestricted access to the buildings without impacting on operations. This required building good working relations and close liaison between the client, end users and surveying team.

epe_description_1: This Secondary School underwent a major refurbishment in 2020–2021, modernising facilities, improving energy efficiency, and enhancing learning environments across the historic and newer buildings. Works included remodelling/refurbishment of class space and changing rooms; creation of dining hall including food preparation area; external works creating seating area with associated hard and soft landscaping.
epe_description_2: Project Quantity Surveyor responsible for taking the Project from Feasibility through to Completion. Preparing Stage Cost Reports; Procurement action; Post Contract Works.
epe_description_3: The Project was due to be undertaken in four phased Sections. Due to Covid the programme was revised which saw the school being closed allowing work faces opened concurrently. The school heating system was life expired and lacked any control valves to enable areas to be isolated. The age and efficiency of the heating system forced a major design change for the proposed dining hall to a standalone underfloor heating system. In addition, as the pipes were frozen, new valves were installed enabling works to continue. Overall, this was seen as a benefit as the hall could be hired out to external groups without any reliance on the school heating system.

epe_description_1: Over 40 projects of varying size and complexity, remodelling and upgrading the Hospital facilities including CT Scanner suite; MRI installation; Pharmacy Robot; Mental Health Wards.
epe_description_2: Providing Quantity Surveying Support preparing feasibility studies for the Outline Business Case, Stage Cost Reports and tender pricing documents for the Client.
epe_description_3: Working on projects which cover the wide range of Hospital activities/ services involving specialist equipment. The remodelling of the Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) suite and Computed Tomography (CT) scanner facilities require the removal of the existing scanners and remodelling the rooms including the use of lead lining to the CT scanner room and total radio-frequency radiation screening for the MRI suite. The use of a PFI Contract means that every change is a variation to the Contract and therefore needs to be reflected in the Maintenance costs arising from the additions and omissions to the asset register. This is an ongoing issue for the Client as the accuracy of the original as-built drawings (if there are any) cannot be guaranteed.

epe_description_1: This is a Passivhaus housing development in the county known for its energy efficiency and sustainable design. It features development of 76 mixed Affordable (52) and Open Market (24) Housing Development that is complimented by landscape spaces and street design that creates a compelling narrative.
epe_description_2: Quantity Surveyor responsible for the Construction Stage activities; Valuations; Client Cost Reports
epe_description_3: The Project was undertaken as a Joint Venture between the county and a local firm. All works had to be valued and reported by Client, with the units required to exceed Technical Housing Standards The works were completed in Sections, allowing early handover to the Client. The phasing had to allow for the completion of the building works with minimal disruption to the occupied apartments/houses.

epe_description_1: Between 2016 and 2017, a Junior School in the city underwent structural investigations due to concerns about subsidence. The school, originally built in the Victorian era with mid-20th century additions, showed signs of structural movement, particularly in areas constructed with hard bricks and cement mortar, which are less tolerant to seasonal shifts. The survey noted cracking in walls, decayed plaster, and uneven flooring, consistent with subsidence-related issues. To remedy this the project involved management of temporary raking shores and pattress ties to gable ends and enabling works for a cantilevered mini piling contract at a Victorian school in the city.
epe_description_2: Procurement tender procedure; managing project from start to finish; final account preparation
epe_description_3: Key challenges were the underpinning of the site and the need to undertake the project on a live site. The underpinning project was carried out on a live site and included necessary internal remodelling to provide temporary decant for classrooms and other spaces impacted by subsidence. For example, the floor had sloped to such an extent the teacher was sitting on a slope before we reconstructed the floor. The contractor also required the use of a classroom for their site office. The classroom alterations were required to be completed during the holiday for the start of Autumn term. The underpinning works progressed through the autumn term completing in November. As part of the decant process to enable works to continue and to meet all health and safety aspects, the classbase, kitchen and toilets affected were boarded off internally completely from the staff/children and externally the gable end and asphalt adjacent required fencing off as deep excavations were necessary for the piling.

epe_description_1: A Primary School, located in the area, is a vibrant and inclusive community school serving children aged 5 to 11. The toilets were refurbished in 2024 to address issues related to ageing infrastructure, hygiene, and accessibility, ensuring the facilities met modern standards for safety, cleanliness, and inclusivity. The project involved refurbishment of boys and girls KS2 toilets and included the creation of additional toilet in cupboard – flooring, solid grade laminate cubicles, cistern ductwork and vanity troughs.
epe_description_2: Procurement tender procedure; managing project from start to finish; final account preparation
epe_description_3: The project faced several challenges, including delays in material deliveries, health and safety concerns, and issues with workmanship and site coordination. These factors contributed to an extended project timeline, which grew from an initial six weeks to thirty weeks. During the works, changes in site management were made to help improve progress and communication. Throughout the contract period, I maintained positive working relations with the school. Following a review meeting with the contractor, they offered to redecorate both the boys’ and girls’ toilets and several internal doors as a goodwill gesture. The school was patient and cooperative throughout, and relations between ourselves and the school remain strong.

epe_description_1: The project involved the removal of Crittall windows and softwood doors and replacing with uPVC windows and aluminium doors. This was required as the original single glazed ill-fitting steel Crittall frames with single ply board beneath offered poor thermal performance. The softwood doors with single glazed units were splitting and despite external redecorations the paint was delaminating, and the doors were nearing the end of their serviceable life.
epe_description_2: Procurement tender procedure; managing project from start to finish; final account preparation
epe_description_3: Challenges included Asbestos removal of packers to the Crittall windows An asbestos R&D survey showed inconclusive. This resulted in the need for a watching brief at the start of contract to determine the use of asbestos containing materials in the packers and this could not be carried out until the windows were removed. We could not assume that if one window was clear the rest would follow. The asbestos contractor needed the windows out to ascertain if the material for the packers were asbestos and subsequently if notifiable. It was deemed notifiable so the windows had to be boarded up while we waited for the removal of the Crittall windows - also, three high level windows could not be removed externally as the school’s office summer building was directly sited beneath them; the school had to allow to clear out a large storeroom prior to the removal of these windows. The school also had issues with dust and debris damaging their hall curtains/walls/floor which the contractor addressed. We worked closely with the school informing them of the plan to move the project forwards, but that any dust a debris would be managed and minimised where possible. The project was completed on time and the internal finishings were cleaned. The school was happy with the result.

epe_description_1: In 2021, This Tower Block, underwent refurbishment to enhance residential quality and sustainability. Works focused on the roof, concrete repairs and window and door replacement which supported the overall objective of improved energy efficiency, and upgrading of roof access and security. Working with the client we contributed to the wider regeneration of the estate into a vibrant, community-focused urban living environment.
epe_description_2: Provided design services from RIBA Stage 3 / 4, and Project Lead, Contract Administrator from RIBA Stage 5+
epe_description_3: The building is an occupied tower block. As a result, we were responsible for managing clients and residents to ensure a safe working environment of a high-risk building.

epe_description_1: In 2021, this Tower Block, underwent refurbishment to enhance residential quality and sustainability. Works focused on the roof, concrete repairs and window and door replacement which supported the overall objective of improved energy efficiency, and upgrading of roof access and security. Working with the client we contributed to the wider regeneration of the estate into a vibrant, community-focused urban living environment.
epe_description_2: Provided design services from RIBA Stage 3 / 4, and Project Lead, Contract Administrator from RIBA Stage 5+.
epe_description_3: The building is an occupied tower block and had to manage clients, residents and ensure safe working practice of a high-risk building.

epe_description_1: Full refurbishment of a care home, work included decoration, kitchen fitting, fixtures and fittings replaced, demolition, landscape works and fire safety works.
epe_description_2: Provided design services from RIBA Stage 3 / 4, and Project Lead, Contract Administrator from RIBA Stage 5+.
epe_description_3: The home was occupied during the works with very vulnerable people living there. It took very careful planning and organisation for the project to be completed.

epe_description_1: This is a multifunctional community health and sports hub located in close proximity of a city Stadium. The development includes three artificial grass football pitches and a large car park. The main pavilion houses a range of community facilities: football changing rooms, a public cafe with kitchen and servery, a pharmacy, a GP surgery with multiple consultation and treatment rooms, administrative offices, and a first-floor gym with dedicated changing facilities and additional office space for medical staff.
epe_description_2: Temporary project lead through the planning phase. Created and submitted drawings for the planning application, achieving successful approval. Led and organised documentation for planning submission as well as surveys identification and quotation. Participated in and facilitated one of the public consultation days. Maintained coordination between design updates and client/stakeholder feedback.
epe_description_3: The inclusion of a GP surgery and pharmacy required alignment with NHS and clinical spatial standards. The project had strong community interest, making the consultation process particularly impactful.

epe_description_1: This is a community-focused sports development consisting of three new artificial football pitches and a central pavilion building. The pavilion includes player and staff changing facilities, a café with kitchen and service areas, as well as spaces for community and foundation use. The site also incorporates a car park, bicycle storage, and integrates an existing grass pitch.
epe_description_2: Assisted with planning and tender documentation preparation. Compiled and organised design and technical documents for submission. Developed and presented alternative layout options to the client. Supported design revisions and produced updated visualisations. Collaborated with the team to coordinate client feedback into design adjustments
epe_description_3: Visualisation work helped the client understand and select between spatial configurations. A key focus was balancing accessibility, community engagement, and sports functionality.

epe_description_1: Located in the local area, formerly an Adult Training Centre demolished circa 2016, was identified under the ‘site allocations plan’ (SAP) as a potential development site for a permanent ‘gypsy & traveller’ site. Provision of a new site is necessary to meet the Authority’s statutory obligations for facilities of this type and was subsequently ratified under planning policy HG 6. THe street is a 0.72-hectare site identified as being capable of accommodating approximately 8 pitches.
epe_description_2: Produced initial site layout sketches exploring both low-density and high-density pitch options. Identified and arranged topographical and utilities surveys to support early-stage decision-making. Created a planning policy tracker to highlight potential planning constraints and considerations. Developed a design brief tracker outlining spatial and functional requirements for each plot. Collaborated with external consultants across Landscape, Highways, and Quality Assurance to inform viable site design options.
epe_description_3: Early feasibility required balancing policy compliance with the client’s flexibility in density and future expansion. The site’s SAP allocation helped guide its development potential, but also introduced constraints around access, amenity provision, and environmental sensitivities. Co-designing with multidisciplinary teams at such an early stage required careful coordination to avoid rework at planning. Delivering two contrasting but realistic layout strategies was essential to give the client a meaningful choice moving forward.

epe_description_1: This project encompassed conversion of existing garage sites owned by the Council and Essex to residential houses to be used as social housing. The sizes of plots varied and the proposal incorporated 2 to 7 units of terraced houses with amenity space and car parking.
epe_description_2: Lead Designer from RIBA Stage 2; Designer from Stage 0-2; TA role from Stage 4 onwards
epe_description_3: All remaining garage sites, are usually small and come with challenges eg right of way, overlooking and underground services that need to be avoided or moved.

epe_description_1: The practice was appointed to carry out the post-planning RIBA stages for a 62-bed care home scheme in Berkshire, adjacent to a housing development. This project sought to provide a high-quality living environment that integrates seamlessly with the surrounding community.
epe_description_2: Provided architectural assistance from RIBA Stage 4b. My responsibilities including producing amendments to GA plans, elevations, fire strategy and proposed ceiling type drawings in line with the client’s vision. As well as producing typical construction detail drawings, window, door and art stone schedules, setting out drawings and room layouts in line with the client model and RDS.
epe_description_3: Careful negotiation with planning was required as the clients desired number of beds differed to the approved scheme. The project also involved coordinating a variety of materials and interfaces, demanding precise detailing to ensure vital coherence and performance.

epe_contract_type: Design and Build, JCT Building Contract.
epe_description_1: A 66-bed new build care home situated on the land in Kent. This application aimed to supersede a previous approval granted for a 78-bed care home for the elderly which received permission in August 2021. The design was a T shape care home aimed to support residential care as well as caring for those living with dementia. The home features a wide range of facilities including a cinema, sensory room and private dining room. The care home was designed to BREEAM ‘Very Good’.
epe_description_2: Responsible for delivering architectural services following planning consent through stages 3-6 and assisting in technical tender drawings covering various aspects of the design including brick detailing, fire strategy drawings room layouts.
epe_description_3: Challenges presented due to its intricate brick detailing combined with Metframe construction. Client led design changes during the process necessitated careful spatial reconfiguration to minimise costly alterations to the pre-engineered steel frame.

epe_description_1: The site was a former care home in disrepair, granted planning permission in July 2021 for a 90-bed scheme to support exceptional elderly and dementia care. Facilities included a large cinema, hairdressers, a pub, terrace lounges, large dining rooms as well as an arts and crafts room and physio. Originally brought onto the scheme during RIBA stage 4, my role within the Harrogate scheme would largely involve the coordination of technical drawings, commenting on other consultant drawings and coordinating room layout proposals with the interior design team.
epe_description_2: Responsible for assisting lead architect to deliver architectural services through work stages 4-7 including snagging documentation prior to practical completion. Attendance to monthly site meetings, finalising elements in coordination with subcontractors, as well as generally responding to any contractor RFI’s alongside the supervision of the project Architect.
epe_description_3: Challenges to the project included tight budgets, and delays during construction due to inclement weather. Another challenge lay in delivering the care home as a turnkey project for a Private Care company, the end user. It was essential to ensure the client, and the end user were fully aligned throughout the process. The scheme was selected as one of the four finalists for the UK Luxury Care Home Award 2025, from a list of 150 care homes. The care home was designed to BREEAM ‘Very Good’.

epe_description_1: A large, three-storey extension is being developed for an existing Special School to accommodate 80 secondary-age and Post-16 pupils. The project includes extensive external works on a constrained urban site, featuring dedicated areas for pupil drop-off and collection, a multi-use games area (MUGA), and various play and social spaces. The new building houses class bases, specialist classrooms, support spaces, a hall designed for dining and trampoline use, and a life skills room. A key aspect of the design is the integration of a link building to ensure seamless circulation and continuity with the existing school facilities.
epe_description_2: Project lead up to novation at RIBA Stage 3. School/client liaison and advisory thereafter and providing information regarding planning requirements and design intent. An architectural technologist became project lead for Nordwick for Stages 4 and 5.
epe_description_3: This is a constrained site with minibus movements to co-ordinate to ensure that pupils arrive and depart in a calm state of mind. Mature trees needed to be retained whilst not presenting a hazard from the pupils. The school wanted the extension and existing school to feel like a single institution, so it was paramount to design safe, continuous circulation throughout the combined buildings and for the pupils to be able to identify with all the areas relevant to them.

epe_description_1: In the delivery of this project, one wing of an existing primary school has been refurbished to create a dedicated base for 16 pupils with special educational needs, primarily those with autism and behavioural or learning difficulties. The internal works included the development of spacious group rooms, play areas, an office, a kitchen, a calm room, a sensory room, and fully accessible WCs and a hygiene room. Externally, the project involved designing new access routes, secure boundaries, and a covered, purpose-built play and curriculum area to support the pupils’ specific needs in a safe and engaging environment.
epe_description_2: Project lead including client and school liaison, working with the contractor and contract administrator.
epe_description_3: The existing mainstream classrooms were not suitable for special needs and there were spaces which were out of sight. The design brought all the pupils’ areas up to standard and created a flow of movement which allowed easy supervision. The previously awkward spaces are now used as staff areas. The secure external play areas have been very successful and are in constant use in all weathers.

epe_description_1: The refurbishment of a Council head office was undertaken to enhance accessibility, improve sustainability, and create a more welcoming environment for both staff and visitors.
epe_description_2: I was assisting the architectural project lead and responsible for maintaining the design intent. In practice, the complexity of developing co-ordinated design through Stage 4 required several workshop-style design meetings both internally and with the contractor, with support from the architectural project lead and our design director.
epe_description_3: The façade of the building is a 19th century building which makes a significant contribution to the streetscape in the city centre. However, the height of the entrances and fenestration caused difficulties in upgrading the services between the floors – there was not enough depth for the usual contemporary range of ducts and plant. Inter-disciplinary workshops achieved bespoke solutions that have resulted in light, airy spaces which preserve the historical character of the building.

epe_description_1: Remodelling of WC and Calm Room areas to achieve minimum dimensions required for Calm Room by the City Council. Replacement of existing Mechanical & Electrical services to suit new arrangement.
epe_description_2: Led the project from RIBA 1 to RIBA 6 and produced all architectural design information. Managed design input from M&E and Acoustic Engineers and Clerks of Work.
epe_description_3: Constrained programme; project was to be delivered over 6-week Summer holidays and ready for occupation by SEN pupils at start of new school term.

epe_description_1: Remodelling and change of use of LCC office property into 7-bed residential unit for let by city council. Improvements to fabric performance and several future-proofing accessibility measures were included in the scope.
epe_description_2: Development of RIBA 1 design. Submission of planning and change of use applications. Supported in administering requests for variations and chaired pre-start, progress, and handover meetings.
epe_description_3: Challenging relationship to navigate between Contractor, Client, and Nordwick. Greatly extended programme of works and numerous contentious variations to approve. Complications related to project forming part of wider 80+ property contract.

epe_description_1: Extensive refurbishment of existing Grade II listed religious building. Partial demolition and remodelling of 1970’s link building.
epe_description_2: Project lead, production of all drawings at all stages. Coordination of surveyors, consultants, and other designers both internal and external.
epe_description_3: Independently managing a private client and navigating the higher information requirements imposed by listed building status.

epe_description_1: Managing the County Council Rates Bills for their estate portfolio across the county, via 7 Billing Authorities.
epe_description_2: Checking Rates Bills against Riverlake software calculations and C2 data to ensure correct liability and cost figures for each premises, and bulk upload of c.230 Rates Bills via Master Schedule to CPT Finance by end of June deadline on annual basis.
epe_description_3: county estates portfolio is a constantly moving entity and county liability must be checked via colleague reviews to ensure that each site is liable for the bills presented to CPT Finance at the bulk upload data transfer. The value of the processed Rates Bills in total each year is in excess of £3m.

epe_description_1: Managing Central County Constabulary Rates Bills for their estate portfolio across the central region, via 9 Billing Authorities.
epe_description_2: Checking Rates Bills against Riverlake software calculations and G drive data to ensure correct liability and cost figures for each premises, and bulk upload of c.45 Rates Bills via Master Schedule to Strategic Finance by mid-July deadline on annual basis.
epe_description_3: With Central County Constabulary estate portfolio being initially unfamiliar in terms of the geography it was a challenge to develop knowledge of locations for police stations and offices. This was developed over time. The value of the processed Rates Bills in total each year is in excess of £1.8m.

epe_description_1: Staff conducting inspections at Police stations and offices for Asset Valuation projects across the country are required by Police Forces to have been vetted centrally prior to gaining entry to each site.
epe_description_2: Responsible for guiding each staff applicant through the Police National Vetting Service Portal, from the initial Proof of ID exchange with central Vetting Unit to providing access for staff to complete their online vetting applications to deadline.
epe_description_3: Ensuring that each application was submitted to deadline via the online Portal process was a high priority, given that rolling clearances expire every 3 years so staff conducting asset valuation inspections could be refused entry to Police stations if not completed in a timely manner.

epe_description_1: A requirement to raise the flood wall level of a named Dock at a Royal Naval Dockyard was identified. This involved demolishing a section of the floodwall along the whole length of the dock, and casting a new concrete wall above. The dock is used for the defueling of the decommissioned nuclear submarines at the dockyard.
epe_description_2: Inspection, approval and sign off of all concrete works required for the construction of the new floodwall. This included checking that all reinforcement cages were compliant with the design prior to pouring of concrete. Pre-pour checks, approval of all concrete mixes prior to pouring, and post pour checks.
epe_description_3: The Submarine Refit Complex (SRC at an Unamed Dockyard is a Ministry of Defence asset. All personnel working within the dockyard are required to be competent in their fields and are required to obtain full security clearance. The design of the floodwall refurbishment was highly complex, and due diligence was required in ensuring all works were carried out to the high standards required for a nuclear licensed site. The ability to identify non-compliance in reinforcement as per design was required, as well as tolerances.

epe_description_1: A 5 yearly inspection regime of all civil assets is required to all operating nuclear sites. These are managed under Licence Condition 28 (LC28). All civil and structural assets on the site are required to be inspected by a competent structural engineer on a 5 year basis. Any breaches in licence conditions, e.g. building or structures becoming unfit for purpose can result in the loss of the operating licence for the site. Power Station 1 operated two reactors. The station is a highly complex site with numerous buildings and systems.
epe_description_2: All buildings on the site were required to be fully inspected, and any defects reported. I was responsible for advising on remediation of structural shortfalls, and for the design of temporary works required for works to be carried out. Also, I was a resident engineer at the site during the replacement of the reactor building roof. This involved removal of the existing roof membrane over an area of approx.. 200m2. I was required to approve the design and installation of the new roof covering and to make daily checks on the installation. During my time at Power Station 1, I mentored a placement student who is now a lead project engineer at the site
epe_description_3: The most challenging aspect was the requirement to provide remediation solutions for highly complex buildings in both concrete and steel framed buildings. These had to be compliant with strict nuclear regulations. Each proposal was required to go through the modifications process at the site. This involved writing submissions, justifying the proposal from a nuclear safety perspective, and presenting the submission to the nuclear safety panel for approval.

epe_description_1: A new nuclear power station is being constructed in the UK. The project is a large complex infrastructure project which is essential to provide energy for approximately 60 years. The Nuclear reactor building is an extremely complex mix of steel and concrete fame construction
epe_description_2: Principal Engineer for the Nuclear Island, responsible for responding to technical queries, Field Change Requests, and Non Conformance Reports. These were generated by the civil contractor. Most concerned deviations from the design for reinforcement. My role was to either approve the contractor’s proposal to rectify non-conformances, or to propose alternatives. As I was working for the Nuclear New Build/Reactor Island team, my proposals were required to satisfy nuclear safety regulations. I was required to categorise the nuclear safety significance of the deviation or proposal and submit to approved categorisers for assessment/approval.
epe_description_3: There were many challenges in meeting the requirements of nuclear safety when proposing solutions to non-conformances, and to approving Field Change Requests. The contractor required prompt responses to their queries as construction/concrete pours could not be delayed. An understanding of the requirements and proposals offered by the contractor was sometimes difficult because of language barriers and unclear descriptions

epe_description_1: A new two storey, six classroom teaching block with associated facilities, linked back to existing school ‘quad’ block.
epe_description_2: Lead Designer and Lead Consultant from RIBA Stage 2 onwards.
epe_description_3: The existing school campus is already well developed and therefore the site of this building was relatively restricted, lying in close proximity to a retaining wall on the site boundary, existing buildings, and playground areas. Part of the solution to this challenge was to link the new building to via an ‘unheated lobby’ such that the new build was thermally separated from the older less efficient buildings.

epe_description_1: New 100 place SEN school on green field site for pupils with Social, Emotional and Mental Health needs.
epe_description_2: Supported the Lead Architect as a technician through RIBA Stage 3 and the beginning of RIBA Stage 4 before taking on the Lead Designer/Lead Consultant role through the remainder of RIBA Stage 4 and RIBA Stage 5.
epe_description_3: Various challenges to contend with throughout the project, the delivery programme was tight and as such the design was completed without the benefit of an end-user who wasn’t brought onboard until the commencement of RIBA Stage 5, resulting in some mid-construction changes which had to be carefully managed with the contractor to limit their programme implication.

epe_description_1: New community centre and doctors’ surgery on steep and challenging site in the city. The two buildings are separated but share a common design aesthetic and are linked via a central public plaza.
epe_description_2: Responsible for assisting lead architect to deliver architectural services through all work stages. Acting as the Employer’s Site Representative (ESR) through RIBA Stage 5.
epe_description_3: The site provided by the housing developer for the project is steep dropping several meters from one side to the other resulting in a split-level design approach and the need for multiple retaining elements to create plateaus, creating some complex detailing challenges to be resolved.

epe_description_1: UK College 2 is a large secondary school and sixth form in the area. Its new state-of-the-art Mathematics Building, completed in a 44-week project, features containing 8 bright, modern classrooms with ancillary spaces, with a central linking space containing student social and workspaces, and principal entrance at ground floor.
epe_description_2: Led on concept design all the way through to detailed design and construction on site.
epe_description_3: The layout was worked out carefully to fit a tight site with an awkward shape, and within a busy operational campus. The Phase 1 building had to be designed in such a way that it functioned independently and made sense within the campus without the phase 2 portion, as the gap of time between each phase being built was likely to be several years.

epe_description_1: Conversion and refurbishment of the Grade II Listed Centre into a 30 place SEMH (social, emotional & mental health) school for children aged 11-16. The Centre was built in 1895 as a grammar school and was later used as a primary school and then most recently an adult education centre.
epe_description_2: Responsible for delivering architectural services following planning consent through stages 1-6 and overseeing small team to deliver the project.
epe_description_3: The buildings Grade II Listed status restricted external and internal alterations to the building and sensitive design decisions were required to achieve the desired layout. Birds nesting in the loft space delayed the installation of the ventilation system.

epe_description_1: This Education Campus is an all through school with nursery, primary and secondary provisions on one site. The first three phases of a planned expansion the secondary school to 1200 places by fitting out first and second floor shell & core spaces with five new classroom, two science laboratories and a science prep room. Internal alterations were carried out within the existing school to enlarge the dining hall, create a staff room and divide the main hall and drama studio with anoperable p
epe_description_2: Responsible for delivering architectural services following planning consent through stages 3-6 and overseeing small team to deliver the project.
epe_description_3: The school was occupied through out the project and the logistics of maintaining separation between the construction works and the pupils was very challenging. The new operable wall in the main hall was almost 7m high.

epe_description_1: This project underwent multiple progressive design stages as part of a wider school consolidation programme led by the school trust. The element of the consolidation efforts, are involved in surrounds the site, with the renovation of an existing school building and the construction of a two-storey new-build classroom block. The new building will provide classrooms for the primary school on the upper ground floor and playrooms for the nursery on the lower ground floor.
epe_description_2: During the initial Stage 03 and Stage 04 design phases, I acted as technical support to the lead architect. My primary focus was the development and detailing of the two-storey new-build element, specification writing, and supporting both the second technician and lead architect with the renovation and additional new-build extension. When a redesign became necessary due to complications described below, I assumed the role of project lead, supported by the technician.
epe_description_3: The project has faced multiple challenges, but we have worked hard to overcome them and are now progressing into Stage 05, which is about to commence. The COVID-19 pandemic presented one of the major challenges, as the initial Stage 04 design phase had to be completed entirely online. We overcame this by maintaining constant communication, ensuring coordination was upheld throughout. A second significant issue arose just as we were preparing to commence construction the first time: the contractor entered administration, resulting in a stand-down period. The timing of this event led to a significant increase in costs when retendering. Due to the fixed budget, we overcame this setback by redesigning the scheme and carrying out a substantial value engineering (VE) exercise. This was achieved through strong collaboration with the client and consultant teams.

epe_contract_type: JCT Intermediate Contract with Contractor's Design 2016
epe_description_1: The development phase of the National Lottery Heritage Fund application process validated a Country Park’s status as a specialist centre for outdoor teaching and learning. It was identified that extending and improving the park’s facilities would enable greater access for a diverse range of visitors, establishing the Country Park as a hub for the local community. The project included the extension of the existing visitor centre to provide a new main lobby, Changing Places bathroom, and public WCs, as well as the renovation of the existing visitor centre and the construction of a new workshop building. The new workshop building houses a flexible community workshop room, a ranger workshop, and a garage for vehicle and tool storage.
epe_description_2: I joined the project at Stage 04, with responsibility for the technical design of the workshop and for specification writing across the entire project. I also supported the lead designer during the construction phase, overseeing the workshop building element.
epe_description_3: Due to the workshop’s location within a forest environment and the use of an innovative under-raft insulation system, complications arose concerning the required reduced dig levels, heave protection, and under-slab insulation. These challenges were overcome by working closely with the contractor and system manufacturer to develop details that met thermal performance requirements while accommodating the achievable reduced dig levels.

epe_description_1: The project involved replacement of the VRF system for the whole centre including all pipework, electrical wiring works.
epe_description_2: Provided M&E assistance from RIBA Stage 4, and Project Lead, Contract Administrator from RIBA Stage 5+. Project communication with client, tenant and contractor. Monitoring the installation progress and workmanship. Joining the test and commissioning and review the result. Validation of the payment based on the progress.
epe_description_3: Key challenge was to minimise the suspension time of air conditioning system as the centre was still in operation. For achieving the purpose, to arrange the installation of the condenser units in advance. After the leakage and electrical test of the condensers, changeover of the existing indoor units to the new condenser system. Thereafter, to replace the indoor unit room by room gradually. Finally, the project was completed successfully and smoothly.

epe_description_1: A student roost involves two blocks,  with total 137 cluster and studio flats that replaced the mechanical services of MVHR, MV units and HWS system with HW cylinders, expansion vessels and associated valves. Before going forward of the replacement, validation for the major equipment such a. s MVHR / MV units and the HW cylinders were completed with a comprehensive report for the client.
epe_description_2: Responsible for delivering MEP services following planning consent with tender procedure from client.
epe_description_3: Key challenges were minimising the effect to the operation of the Student Roost since it would be kept in operation during the work. As proposed, the contractor would carry out the replacement work of the MVHR and HW cylinder for each flat within two days. In this connection, a well preparation including the material delivery, good understanding of the replacement work, comprehensive survey before commencement of work by the contractor was required. After the work was going smooth, two flats would be commenced for the work simultaneously to speed up the progress.

epe_description_1: The commercial building was equipped with chiller plant, gas boiler and AHU system originally which are deteriorated. It is proposed to replace the air conditioning system with new VRF system for the whole building including modification work of the existing AHU.
epe_description_2: Responsible for delivering MEP services to design the new VRF system including the cooling / heating load calculation based on the modelling.
epe_description_3: During the design stage, it was considered the ventilation supplied by AHU would be disruption to the tenant which cannot be carried out simultaneously with the VRF installation. It was proposed that, begin phased process of installing the office VRF system on a floor-by-floor basis. Replace FCUs zonally to further minimise disruption and align the installation of VAV boxes (for the demand led ventilation) with the FCU replacement. After the FCU and VRF system installation completed, undertake process of replacing AHU fans, installing new AHU housing with thermal wheel heat recovery, and installing a DX heat pump. Doing these works during the spring period should minimise the disruptive impact of brief periods without ventilation.

epe_description_1: Based on the fire strategy report, the smoke extraction system for the shopping centre should be redesigned for the compliance purpose. To complete the survey for the existing smoke extraction system and the electrical power supply system for the design.
epe_description_2: Responsible for planning of the modification of the LV switch board, replacement of the smoke extraction fans and BMS control panel.
epe_description_3: The new smoke extraction flow rate as required by the report was much higher than the existing, it is required to replace the existing eight smoke extraction fans. However, the existing space and power supply for the six out of eight smoke extraction fans were not suitable for replacing a larger fan. Survey was conducted for the existing LV main board to check the feasibility of larger power supply for the new smoke extraction system and modification for the LV main switch board was proposed to the client.

epe_description_1: Nordwick Planning Consultancy prepared and submitted a planning application for the redevelopment of land south of the county, on behalf of East UK Borough Council 2 as part of its Strategic Housing Delivery plan (SHDP), which as part of its remit identified a number of sites across the borough that could contribute to the Council’s objective of delivering affordable housing with low carbon emission and ‘green’ developments. Your
epe_description_2: Norwick Planning Consultancy was responsible for preparation and submission of planning application for redevelopment of the site to provide 40, one and two bedroom apartments and community room, comprising 100% affordable housing and Zero Carbon (in use) for the Borough Council. Any specific
epe_description_3: As part of the development of the scheme we worked closely with the borough planners, county Highways, the LLFA and county Police address any issues at an early stage and received no objections from statutory consultees to the planning application submission. We also worked closely with existing residents, neighbouring properties and the local community through our public consultation events and sought to address relevant concerns where possible. The proposal gained planning consent at committee in December 2022 and will deliver a high-quality affordable housing scheme which is energy efficient and zero carbon in use and exceeds planning policy requirement.

epe_description_1: This multi-award winning development of sustainable Passivhaus family homes was the first project for East UK District Council 3. Nordwick was appointed as planning consultant to prepare a planning application to develop the former garden of a large private house just outside the area, for housing.
epe_description_2: Nordwick Planning Consultancy played a pivotal role in preparing, submitting and monitoring the planning application to deliver development on this publicly owned land, providing 14 energy efficient family homes, exceeding the affordable housing policy requirements, delivering environmental benefits including provided a community woodland whilst still delivering profit to the developer.
epe_description_3: The development of the site for housing presented a number of obstacles. The site was located outside the defined settlement limit for Hellesdon on a heavily constrained site by trees with access from a busy A road. The project had to be managed sensitively in the planning process to overcome several planning challenges associated with trees, ground conditions, open space requirements, affordable housing, refuse and servicing, archaeology, highways and viability issues to ensure that planning permission was granted within a very tight timescale in a manner that avoided the need for onerous pre-commencement planning conditions.

epe_description_1: Nordwick were instructed by East UK District Council 2 (the client) to act as planning consultant as part of the team to deliver a major development scheme at a town Riverside. Your
epe_description_2: Nordwick were instructed to prepare and submit a planning application for the redevelopment of the Riverside for a mixed use scheme to include; Hotel (64 bedrooms); Two screen cinema; Ground floor retail units; Car parking; and Large public realm area. Any specific
epe_description_3: The planning application successfully achieved planning consent in 2012 and work began on the site in June 2015 with construction completed in October 2016. The Light Cinema opened to the public in December 2016 and a the national hotel chain  is also open. There are also restaurants, cafes and a gym with a landscaped public realm area down to the river.

epe_service: Project Landscape Architect and Contract Administrator
epe_description_1: Sports Pitches was a project for the design and contract management to provide two new grass sports pitches and associated access and car parking and soft landscaping as replacement facilities for pitches lost to development on another site in the city. The design had to be designed sympathetically to not disrupt the character of the green belt location. Roles and Responsibilities - My involvement was as Project Landscape Architect leading a multi-disciplinary team both internally and external consultants and followed by acting as Contract Administrator during the construction phase.
epe_description_3: The site for the pitches lies within the green belt so the planning process was not straight forward and required additional steps to prove the development was acceptable within the green belt. A high-pressure gas main crosses the site, which was a significant constraint which required in depth consultation with the statutory authority to design a suitable acceptable and safe design solution.

epe_description_1: This is a new build specialist housing project for Adults with Autism and complex learning difficulties and staff support facilities. The landscape design including the building surrounds for both residents and staff including access and resident’s private and communal gardens. The communal gardens needed to provide a calming, safe and secure outdoor space for the resident’s enjoyment and to assist in the provision of therapies for residents to help with their journeys to independent living. Roles and Responsibilities - Project: I was Landscape Architect on the project working as part of multi-disciplinary team and consulting with the client team to achieve planning approval (RIBA Stage3). Following this stage, I provided specialist landscape technical advice to the client to ensure the contractor’s final design followed design intent.
epe_description_3: The key challenges in designing the external spaces revolved around the very specialist nature of the residents’ requirements, these are sometimes opposing so providing outdoor spaces which meet all possible needs was particularly difficult. There were also several TPO trees on and around the site which needed to be protected and incorporated within the site design.

epe_description_1: This project provided a large 3-storey extension to an existing Special Educational Needs School. The project included extensive external works to provide a safe external environment to support the curricular activities of the school. These included outdoor play and social areas along with a fenced 3G artificial grass multi use games area for sports activities. The externals also included the provision for the safe dropping off and picking up of pupils in a secure compound which also had to provide staff and visitor parking outside of the morning and afternoon, secure lines and access arrangements were complex. Roles and Responsibilities - I was the Project Landscape Architect both up to RIBA Stage 3 and following novation to the contractor as part of multi-disciplinary team.
epe_description_3: Key challenges included the design of external spaces for pupils with diverse levels of special needs. As the project was an extension to an existing school the site was very constrained with limited space available to provide the required outdoor provision, and the design had to maximise the site’s potential while working around existing features and mature trees. Site levels also presented challenges to ensure all areas were fully accessible to all pupils regardless of needs.

epe_description_1: We were commissioned to carry out an RIBA 2-6 service for the refurbishment of the building fabric and M&E Planned Maintenance programme for the City Councils primary school stock. We are responsible for providing a comprehensive condition stock surveys of approx. 30 properties per year on a 5-year rotation. Its aim: to determine priority works for the external building fabric (Roofs, external envelope and structural defects) plus the mechanical and electrical works within the schools.
epe_description_2: We were commissioned to provide full design services. We also provided technical advice support to the client on all refurbishment requirements. Our team provided full fabric building surveying design service, project management, mechanical and electrical design, ICT infrastructure design, CDMC, PDBR, quantity surveying and quality management. The design element included liaising with client subcontractors for ICT equipment installations, FFE installation and security systems installation. We were also responsible for attaining planning consent and listed building consent, review and implementation of access and inclusion strategy for the refurbishment.
epe_description_3: The refurbishment brief constantly evolves as the Local Authority reacts to the central government measures over the duration of the programmes. We worked in collaboration with the City Council, and their subcontractors, Town Centre Securities to deliver these programmes.

epe_description_1: We were commissioned to carry out an RIBA 2-6 service for the refurbishment of the building fabric and M&E Planned Maintenance programme for the City Councils primary school stock. Our brief was to provide a multi discipline design and management service (which included a combined fabric, mechanical and electrical refurbishment to each of the properties).
epe_description_2: We provided full fabric building surveying design service, project management, mechanical and electrical design, ICT infrastructure design, CDMC, PDBR, quantity surveying and quality management. The design element included liaising with client subcontractors for ICT equipment installations, FFE installation and security systems installation. We were also responsible for attaining planning consent and listed building consent (when required), review and implementation of access and inclusion strategy for the refurbishment.
epe_description_3: The refurbishment brief constantly evolves as the Local Authority reacts to the central government measures over the duration of the programmes. We worked in collaboration with City Council to deliver against this evolving brief and achieve successful outcomes for the Client.

epe_description_1: This Building is a Grade II-listed property originally built around 1877 as a hotel, public hall, and dining rooms. In 2019, it underwent a significant refurbishment, transforming a disused nightclub and vacant shop units into modern office space for the cities Market operations and City Centre Management.
epe_description_2: We were commissioned to undertake the refurbishment which included providing a full fabric, structural, mechanical and electrical service from RIBA stage 2-6.
epe_description_3: We faced several challenges complying with listed building requirements but resolved them appropriately (including designing false shopfront windows which allowed light into the offices without showing the layout) also designing and installing an air conditioning system to accommodate the conversion. The whole project was delivered on time and on budget.

epe_description_1: Change of use of existing residential units to commercial units in a Victorian Era building that is within the setting of a Grade II* Listed Building. The proposal also comprised new shop fronts and windows for commercial units to enhance the appearance of the area whilst respecting the heritage context. There was a requirement to meet BREEAM ‘Very Good’.
epe_description_2: Role included providing planning assistance in RIBA Stage 3, providing planning advice on validation requirements, preparing supporting documents including planning statement and heritage statement, and co-ordination, preparation and submission of the planning application and acting as agent.
epe_description_3: The building is in the setting of a listed building, so any external changes had to be sensitive to this. Sufficient justification had to be provided regarding the loss of residential units in relation to local planning policies. The scheme was also only able to achieve BREEAM ‘good’ so it was a challenge to justify this in planning policy terms. It was also important to balance the needs of consultees (Conservation Officer vs Designing Out Crime officer) and justify the design choices in this regard through the planning statement. The project was approved at Planning Committee and planning permission was granted subject to conditions.

epe_description_1: Development of a two-storey new build block known as the ‘West Block’ to facilitate 1FE expansion of an existing secondary Academy school from 9FE to 10FE. Construction of a new Multi-Use Games Area (MUGA), a revised access arrangement into the site and various hard and soft landscaping proposals.
epe_description_2: Role has been to provide planning advice through all stages, seek pre-application advice from the relevant consultees, alongside co-ordination, preparation and submission of the planning application in stage 3 and acting as agent. Responsible for preparing Planning Statement, Construction Considerations Statement and Health Impact Assessment in stage 3. Responsibility in stage 4 will be to discharge pre-commencement conditions including the Statutory BNG Condition.
epe_description_3: This site was challenging in terms of residential amenity and managing stakeholders. The site is also very constrained in terms of playing field area so extensive pre-application consultation was carried out with Sport England to reduce delays during application determination. There were also challenges with meeting the mandatory biodiversity net gain (BNG) requirements whilst not negatively impacting the ability to use the site, and aspects to do with deliberate degradation on the site that had to be accounted for in the BNG.

epe_description_1: The client wished to apply for outline planning approval for 6 dwellings to help contribute towards the lack of 5-Year Housing Land Supply (5YHLS) in the District following an update to National Planning Policy.
epe_description_2: Responsible for providing planning advice regarding how to maximise chances of approval on review of previous reasons for refusal/appeal dismissal, advising on validation requirements and preparing and submitting the planning application as well as acting as agent.
epe_description_3: There were challenges to attempt to overcome since outline planning permission was granted on the site in 2019. These included a new landscape character classification for the village which affected development opportunities on open land and sustainability issues related to the sites location. It was important to respect the existing landscape character of the area given the rural nature and ensure that aspects of sustainable development could be improved as far as practically possible. Significant material benefits (such as providing affordable housing even though the site area was under the policy requirement threshold) were suggested to be proposed through the scheme to outweigh any negative impacts and maximise chances of success.

epe_description_1: This Academy is a high-achieving secondary school in the county, catering to students aged 11 to 16. This project is a three-storey standalone teaching block with attached dining hall and kitchen. The teaching block contains general and IT classrooms as well as design and technology workshops. The superstructure is a steel frame with precast concrete planks, robustly designed and detailed in accordance with disproportionate collapse requirements set out in Building Regulations Part A3 for a Category 2b building. The substructure is a pile supported reinforced concrete ground beam foundation solution, with suspended precast concrete beam and block ground floor.
epe_description_2: As ADSE, I was responsible for overseeing and reviewing, checking and approving the project from feasibility and concept, through to detailed design and construction.
epe_description_3: During construction of reinforced concrete pile caps and ground beams, heavy rainfall resulted in flooding of excavations. We devised a strategy with the contractor for segmental phases of foundation construction. This approach allowed localised pumping out and construction to proceed, maintaining programme ready for steel frame erection.

epe_description_1: This Academy is a large, co-educational secondary school and sixth form in county, serving students aged 11 to 18. This project included a two-storey standalone building providing expansion to the campus. The new building incorporates large open internal spaces for a Sports Hall and Workshop. Roofs are flat and at split levels, with central roof light feature to main atrium area of the building. The superstructure is a steel frame with an in-situ composite concrete deck forming the floors and main roof areas. Primary steel floor / roof beams are designed compositely, utilising the composite action between concrete floors and beams to generate efficiencies within the permanent design. The sports hall roof is a structural metal deck. Translucent proprietary cladding has been used, alongside bricks and brick slip panels, all tied to the primary structure, to form the building envelope. The building is robustly designed and detailed in accordance with disproportionate collapse requirements set out in Building Regulations Part A3 for a Category 2b building. The substructure is a traditional concrete strip and pad foundation system, deepening towards the West side of the building to accommodate soil volume change potential adjacent to trees. A suspended precast concrete beam and block ground floor has been adopted throughout.
epe_description_2: As ADSE, I was responsible for overseeing and reviewing, checking and approving the project from feasibility and concept, through to detailed design.
epe_description_3: On the Western building elevation, a tree belt has resulted in the need for localised foundation deepening. Foundation excavation depths here are deeper than typically preferred, however, to avoid having to adopt piled foundations throughout at significant cost increase to the project, we developed a foundation solution and its safe method of construction, to ensure buildability and maintain traditional spread foundations throughout.

epe_description_1: County Hall is the headquarters of East UK County Council 1. This prominent government building houses key administrative offices and supports the delivery of public services across the county. This project involved the refurbishment of an existing 13 storey major council asset, initiated by random failures of the external cladding system. The superstructure is a 1960’s built reinforced concrete frame, typically comprising reinforced concrete floors, beams and columns, with transfer structures at lower levels between basement and main tower area. The substructure is a pile supported reinforced concrete ground beam and pile cap foundation solution. Lateral stability is provided via two primary reinforced concrete stair cores to the main tower, in conjunction with reinforced concrete shear walls throughout. The building is required to satisfy disproportionate collapse requirements in accordance Building Regulations Part A3 for a Category 2b buildings.
epe_description_2: As ADSE and lead structural engineer, I was responsible for interpreting detailed structural reports, surveying the buildings structure, studying and assessing historic structural drawings, scoping and interpreting non-intrusive and intrusive investigations, scoping and assessing concrete testing and repairs. In addition, I was responsible for assessing remodelling proposals and carrying out structural design and detailing of structural modifications, coordinating structural design and detailing of mechanical and cladding installations.
epe_description_3: Several areas of structural remodelling were required to facilitate architectural and building services requirements, as well as the need to assess existing structural elements for additional loading. To do this safely, a strategy of assessing archive structural drawings and details, in conjunction with non-intrusive and intrusive surveying techniques were adopted to corroborate information before undertaking detailed design and construction.

epe_description_1: This SEN is a large special educational needs (SEN) school building in the county, with building segments ranging from single to three storeys. The roofs vary between flat and mono-pitched, and each of the two main school areas house a large hall space for Dining and Sports activities. The superstructure is a steel frame with precast concrete planks, robustly designed and detailed in accordance with disproportionate collapse requirements set out in Building Regulations Part A3 for a Category 2b buildings. The substructure is a combination of traditional shallow spread foundations and pile supported reinforced concrete ground beam foundation solution, with suspended precast concrete beam and block ground floors throughout. Due to the significant length and geometry of the building, and to isolate the transition from traditional to piled foundations, structural movement joints were incorporated within the design.
epe_description_2: As ADSE, I was responsible for overseeing and reviewing, checking and approving the project from feasibility and concept, through to detailed design and construction.
epe_description_3: The significant footprint of the building, and the cranked geometrical form, in conjunction with variation in No.’s of storeys throughout, resulted in a strategy to segregate the main building into 3 isolated, structural sections, by means of introducing full movement joints across the building. This allowed more expensive engineered foundations to be adopted only where needed, whilst also controlling natural movement of the building fabric.

epe_description_1: New Build Sheltered Housing in a local city, is a 3/4 storey assisted living residential care home building for older residents, specifically designed to provide independent living with additional support. This project saw the design and construction of a new building located on a confined site of an original demolished care home which it replaces. The building is required to satisfy horizontal tying requirements of floors / walls in accordance with Building Regulations Part A3 for a Category 2a building. The superstructure is predominantly load bearing masonry, supporting precast concrete floor planks and gang-nail timber trussed roofs. In areas of load transfer and large, clear internal spaces, localised steel framing is adopted to support floor and roof structure. Lateral stability of the building is provided through roof and floor diaphragms, connected to masonry shear walls throughout. The substructure is a traditional shallow concrete strip and pad foundation system.
epe_description_2: As ADSE, I was responsible for overseeing and reviewing, checking and approving the project from feasibility and concept, through to detailed design and construction. This included on-site inspections of critical structural elements.
epe_description_3: Several areas of the internal architectural layout required room arrangements that did not align from floor to floor. This resulted in some localised steel framing to ensure structural transfer of loads down through the building to foundations. This strategy removed the need to adopt a full structural steel or concrete frame solution, allowing traditional load bearing masonry to be adopted.

epe_description_1: This is a modern secondary school in the county, focused on academic excellence, student development, and strong community engagement. This project comprises a new build single storey CDT building, and a single storey extension to the existing main school Dining Hall. In addition, extensive internal remodelling to the existing original 1960’s school building is required. The superstructure of the proposed new buildings is steel frame. The Dining Hall comprises structural metal deck roofing, and the CDT building is a combination of metal deck and precast concrete plank roofing. The substructure comprises pile supported reinforced concrete ground beam, pile cap and raft slab foundations. The CDT building has an elevated suspended reinforced concrete ground floor slab and perimeter reinforced masonry retaining wall to overcome site flooding risks. The project also incorporates the need for gas protection measures and flood resilient construction which are coordinated with the structural design and detailing.
epe_description_2: As ADSE, I was responsible for overseeing and reviewing, checking and approving the project from feasibility and concept, through to detailed design.
epe_description_3: Poor ground conditions, ground gas presence and high water table at the site, as well as flooding risk, resulted in significant challenges to foundation and building design solutions, including the need to coordinate foundation and gas membrane design and detailing, and elevating building foundations and whilst minimising building weights.

epe_description_1: This project involves the internal remodelling of three existing buildings at the Academy. The Academy is a high-achieving secondary school in the county, catering to students aged 11 to 16. Remodelling is a combination of minor remodelling, typically requiring formation of new openings with localised structural support and strengthening, and major remodelling, requiring removal of primary structural walls and subsequent vertical support to the existing roof, whilst maintaining global stability to the building. Science building remodelling is major, and involves the removal of full height, internal shear walls, to facilitate opening up and remodelling of internal classrooms. Intrusive surveying, design, detailing and installation of a new steel frame and foundations, in conjunction with significant temporary works, is required to facilitate the remodelling requirements.
epe_description_2: As ADSE, I was responsible for overseeing and reviewing, checking and approving the project from feasibility and concept, through to detailed design.
epe_description_3: Due to a lack of archived information for the building, the structural design philosophy and behaviour of the existing science block was unclear. By undertaking visual and intrusive inspections of the substructure and superstructure, we were able to fully assess the structural behaviour, reducing the scope of the required structural work. This resulted in reducing cost and programme requirements, allowing the works to be programmed predominantly within school holiday closure periods.

epe_description_1: This historic site in the centre of a local town has been home to various buildings and uses over the preceding 300 years, the most recent and current being known as The Hall was constructed in 1901. Proposed refurbishment works to the clock tower prompted investigations into the structural ability of the roof to support a scaffold system and workforce for the period repair.
epe_description_2: My role was to conduct and coordinate and full building 3D laser scan to facilitate the custom scaffold design and structural assessment.
epe_description_3: Two primary roof trusses responsible for the support of the clocktower and cupola were sandwiched between the first-floor vaulted ceiling and the external roof covering. A convoluted access route through roof voids was necessary to locate and map these trusses while maintaining the tolerance of accuracy as defined by the survey specification.

epe_description_1: During the construction of an adjacent development that used piling (driving steel components into the ground with force causing vibration) as the primary foundation method, staff at the county Museum noticed cracks to masonry and glazing.
